[[German language]] |rels = [[Shia Islam]], [[Sunni Islam]], [[Syriac Christianity]] }} '''Iraqis in Germany''' include migrants from [[Iraq]] to [[Germany]], as well as their descendants. The number of Iraqis in Germany is estimated at around +300,000 people. Of which 122,000 refugees accepted in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecre.org/positions/Iraq_Quest_Summary_Apr04.shtml |title=Population pressures |accessdate=2007-08-19 |publisher=ecre.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807230323/http://www.ecre.org/positions/Iraq_Quest_Summary_Apr04.shtml |archivedate=2007-08-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The Iraqi community is made up of ethnic [[Arabs]], [[Kurds in Iraq|Kurds]], [[Iraqi Turkmen]], as well as smaller minority groups. ==History and population== The number of Iraqis in Germany is estimated at around 300,000. In 2015, out of 2,727 asylum applications for Iraqi refugees, only 8.3 percent were accepted.[http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,507444,00.html The Iraqi Exodus:Number of Iraqi refugees in Germany Surges] Some sources claim there to be just around 40,000 Iraqi refugees residing in Germany.{{Cite web |url=http://www.peopleandplanet.net/doc.php?id=1933# |title=Iraqi refugees in European nations |access-date=2015-03-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927212544/http://www.peopleandplanet.net/doc.php?id=1933# |archive-date=2007-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 2006, Germany granted just 8.3 percent of Iraqi asylum demands, according to the ministry.[http://www.haveeru1.com.mv/english/?page=details&id=18230 Refugees find Germany "1000 times better than Iraq"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2006, Germany received 2,117 applications for asylum from Iraqis, which is the third highest number in the EU. The country is already home to a sizeable Iraqi population, many of whom were granted protection by the German authorities after fleeing persecution from Saddam Hussein’s former regime. However, the recognition rate for Iraqis has fallen from an average of 57 per cent between 1997 and 2001, to a mere 11 per cent for the year 2006, which is one of the lowest in the European Union. However, Germany has adopted another policy towards Iraqi refugees which has distinguished it from all other EU states, the [[Federal Ministry of the Interior (Germany)|German Federal Ministry of the Interior]] has taken the unique step of systematically revoking the refugee status of thousands of Iraqis who were granted protection before 2003. Since the threat of persecution from the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region|Iraqi Ba’ath regime]] is no longer present, 18,000 Iraqi refugees who entered the country before the 2003 invasion have thus had their refugee status revoked, placing them in a situation of uncertainty and precariousness. In June 2007, the German government asked the asylum authorities to temporarily suspend the revocation of refugee status for certain groups of Iraqis such as those from Baghdad, single women, and members of religious or ethnic minorities such as [[Assyrians in Iraq|Iraqi Assyrians]].{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/publ/RESEARCH/470c9be92.pdf |title=Iraqis in Europe |accessdate=2008-02-14 |publisher=unhcr.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906113441/http://www.unhcr.org/publ/RESEARCH/470c9be92.pdf |archivedate=September 6, 2008 }} 70,000+{{cite web | url =http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/L06873099.htm | title =Sweden tightens rules on Iraqi asylum seekers | accessdate =2008-02-14 | publisher =unhcr.org}} It was estimated in April 2007 that 14,000 Iraqis were living with 'tolerated status' in Germany, with the threat of possible imminent deportation hanging over them. ==Notable people== *[[Abu Walaa]], is an Islamic preacher *[[Laith Al-Deen]], pop musician born to Iraqi father and German mother *[[Dunja Hayali]], German journalist and television presenter. *[[Karo Murat]], professional boxer *[[Najem Wali]], novelist and journalist *[[Khalid al-Maaly]], Arab writer and publisher *[[Iqbal al-Qazwini]], Iraqi journalist and novelist. *[[Claudia Basrawi]], German actress and writer born to Iraqi father and German mother *[[Rafid Ahmed Alwan al-Janabi]], German citizen who defected from Iraq *[[Faris Al-Sultan]], Ironman World Championship Born to Iraqi father and German mother ==See also== * [[Arabs in Germany]] * {{Infobox language |name=Kambera |altname=East Sumbanese |region=[[Lesser Sunda Islands]] |states=[[Indonesia]] |speakers=240,000 |date=2009 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Austronesian |fam2=[[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] (MP) |fam3=[[Nuclear Malayo-Polynesian languages|Nuclear MP]] |fam4=[[Central–Eastern Malayo-Polynesian languages|Central–Eastern MP]] |fam5=[[Sumba–Flores languages|Sumba–Flores]] ? |fam6=[[Sumba languages|Sumba]] |fam7=Sumba Island |fam8=Sumbanese |iso3=xbr |glotto=kamb1299 |glottorefname=Kambera |notice=IPA }} '''Kambera''', also known as '''East Sumbanese''', is a [[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian language]] spoken in the [[Lesser Sunda Islands]], [[Indonesia]]. Kambera is a member of Bima-Sumba subgrouping within Central Malayo-Polynesian inside Malayo-Polynesian.Klamer, 1998 The island of Sumba, located in the Eastern Indonesia, has an area of 12,297 km2.Klamer 1998 The name Kambera comes from a traditional region which is close to a town in Waingapu. Because of export trades which concentrated in [[Waingapu]] in the 19th century, the language of the Kambera region has become the bridging language in eastern Sumba. ==Phonology== ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[High vowel|High]] | {{IPA|i iː}} | {{IPA|u uː}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA|e ai}} | {{IPA|o au}} |- ! [[Low vowel|Low]] |colspan="2"| {{IPA|a}}, {{IPA|aː}} |} The [[diphthong]]s {{IPA|/ai/}} and {{IPA|/au/}} function phonologically as the long counterparts to {{IPA|/e/}} and {{IPA|/o/}}, respectively. ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! [[Stop consonant|Stop]] | {{IPA|p}} | {{IPA|t}} | | {{IPA|k}} | |- ! [[Implosive consonant|Implosive]] | {{IPA|ɓ}} | {{IPA|ɗ}} | | | |- ! [[Voiced consonant|Voiced]] [[affricate]] | | | {{IPA|dʒ}} | | |- ! [[Nasal stop|Nasal]] | {{IPA|m}} | {{IPA|n}} | | {{IPA|ŋ}} | |- ! [[Prenasalization|Prenasalized]] [[stop consonant|stop]] | {{IPA|ᵐb}} | {{IPA|ⁿd}} | | {{IPA|ᵑɡ}} | |- ! [[Prenasalization|Prenasalized]] [[affricate]] | | | {{IPA|ᶮdʒ}} | | |- ! [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | | | | | {{IPA|h}} |- ! [[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | {{IPA|l}} | | | |- ! [[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | {{IPA|r}} | | | |- ! [[Semivowel]] | {{IPA|w}} | | {{IPA|j}} | | |- ! [[Prenasalization|Prenasalized]] [[semivowel]] | | | {{IPA|ᶮj}} | | |} Kambera formerly had {{IPA|/s/}}, but a [[sound change]] occurring around the turn of the 20th century replaced all occurrences of former {{IPA|/s/}} with {{IPA|/h/}}. ==Morphology== ===Pronouns and Person Markers=== Personal pronouns are used in Kambera for emphasis/disambiguation and the syntactic relation between full pronouns and [[clitic]]s is similar to that between NPs and clitics. NPs and pronouns have morphological [[Grammatical case|case]]. {| class="wikitable" |+ Personal Pronouns |- ! rowspan=2 align=center| [[Grammatical person|Person]] !! colspan=2 align=center| [[Grammatical number|Number]] |- | align=center| ''Singular'' || align=center| ''Plural'' |- ! 1INC | || align=center| nyuta |- ! 1EXCL | align=center| nyungga || nyuma |- ! 2 | align=center| nyumu || align=center| nyimi |- ! 3 | align=center| nyuna || align=center| nyuda |} Kambera, as a [[head-marking language]], has rich morpho-syntactic marking on its predicators. The pronominal, aspectual and/or mood clitics together with the predicate constitute the nuclear [[clause]]. Definite verbal arguments are crossreferenced on the predicate for person, number and case ([[Nominative case|Nominative]] (N), [[Genitive case|Gentive]] (G), [[Dative case|Dative]] (D), [[Accusative case|Accusative]] (A)). The four main pronominal clitic paradigms are given below. {| class="wikitable" |- ! !! Nominative !! Genitive !! Accusative !! Dative |- ! 1SG | align=center| ku- || align=center| -nggu || align=center| -ka || align=center| -ngga |- ! 2SG | align=center| (m)u- || align=center| -mu || align=center| -kau || align=center| -nggao |- ! 3SG | align=center| na- || align=center| -na || align=center| -ya || align=center| -nya |- ! 1PL.INC | align=center| ta- || align=center| -nda || align=center| ta- || align=center| -nda |- ! 1PL.EXC | align=center| ma- || align=center| -ma || align=center| -kama || align=center| -nggama |- ! 2PL | align=center| (m)i- || align=center| -mi || align=center| -ka(m)i || align=center| -ngga(m)i |- ! 3PL | align=center| da- || align=center| -da || align=center| -ha || align=center| -nja |} '''Examples:''' :{| |(1) ||''apu-nggu' |- | ||granny-1SG.GEN |- | ||colspan=2| "My granny." |}
:{| |(2) ||''ana-na' |- | ||child-3SG.GEN |- | ||colspan=2| "His child." |}
:{| |(3) ||''Kau''||''pa.ta.lunggur-ya''||''na''||''wihi-na'' ||         ||         ||                    |- | ||scratch||CAU.be sore||ART||leg-3SG.GEN||         ||         ||                    |- | ||colspan=7| "He scratched his leg sore." (lit. "He scratched and caused his leg to be sore") |}
:{| |(4) ||''Na-tari-bia''||''nahu''||''angu-na'' |- | ||3SG.NOM-watch-MOD||now||companion-3SG.GEN |- | ||colspan=5| "He just watches his companion." |}
:{| |(5) ||''Ningu''||''uma-nggua'' ||                     |- | ||be.here||house-3SG.GEN||                     |- | ||colspan=5| "I have a house." (lit. "Here is a house of mine.") |}
:{| |(6) ||''Nyuda-ha-ka''||''nahu''||''da''||''ana-nda'' |- | ||they-3PL.ACC-PRF||now||ART||child-1PL.GEN |- | ||colspan=5| "They are our children now." |} The items in the table below mark person and number of the subject when the clause has continuative aspect. {| class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 align=center| [[Grammatical person|Person]] !! colspan=2 align=center| [[Grammatical number|Number]] |- | align=center| ''Singular'' || align=center| ''Plural'' |- ! 1INC | || align=center| -ndanya |- ! 1EXCL | align=center| -nggunya || -manya |- ! 2 | align=center| -munya || align=center| -minya |- ! 3 | align=center| -nanya || align=center| -danya |} '''Examples:''' :{| |(1)||''Lunggur-nanya'' ||''na'' ||''Ihi-na''|| |- | ||scratch-3SG.CONT||ART||body-3SG.GEN |- | ||colspan=3| "He is scratching his body." |} :{| |(2)||''"Laku-nnguya'' ||''ina",'' ||''wa-na''|| |- | ||go-1SG.CONT||mother||say-3SG |- | ||colspan=3| "'I am going, mother," he said.'" |} === Possession === Kambera has a possessive or reflexive noun ''wiki'' ‘self/own’, which can be used to mark possession (1). :{| |(1) |''Uma'' |''wiki'' |''-nggu'' |- | |house |self/own |-1sG |- | | colspan="3" |'My own house' |} ''Wiki'' has the structural properties of a noun and can be used as a nominal modifier (compare 2 & 3), unlike pronouns which must be cross-referenced on the noun with a genitive clitic (3).{{Cite book|title = A Grammar of Kambera|last = Klamer|first = Marian|publisher = Mouton de Gruyter|year = 1998|isbn = 3-11-016187-7|location = Berlin; New York|pages = 130–131}} :{| |(2) |''Uma'' |''witu'' |''-nggu'' |- | |house |grass |-1sG |- | | colspan="3" |'My hut' |} :{| |(3) |''Uma'' |''-nggu'' |''nyungga'' |- | |house |-1sG |I |- | | colspan="3" |'My house' |} As (3) is a possessed noun phrase, the enclitic attaches to the noun. In possessed and modified noun phrases, the genitive enclitic attaches to the noun modifier (4).{{Cite book|title = A Grammar of Kambera|last = Klamer|first = Marian|publisher = Mouton de Gruyter|year = 1998|isbn = 3-11-016187-7|location = Berlin; New York|pages = 48}} :{| |(4) |''Na'' |''uma'' |'''bakul'' |''-nggu'' |- | |ART |house |be big |-1sG |- | | colspan="4" |'My big house' |} In Kambera, where cross-referencing is used, the noun phrase is optional. A verb along with its pronominal markers constitutes a complete sentence. Pronominal clitics are a morphological way of expressing relationships between syntactic constituents such as a noun and its possessor.{{Cite book|title = A Grammar of Kambera|last = Klamer|first = Marian|publisher = Mouton de Gruyter|year = 1998|isbn = 3-11-016187-7|location = Berlin; New York|pages = 60–61}} ==== Possessor Relativisation{{Cite book|title = A Grammar of Kambera|last = Klamer|first = Marian|publisher = Mouton de Gruyter|year = 1998|isbn = 3-11-016187-7|location = Berlin; New York|pages = 320–321}} ==== Possessors can be relativised with a ''ma-'' relative clause. There are three types of clauses used in the relativisation of possessors. The first is when the embedded verb is derived from a relational noun such as mother or child. These derived transitive verbs express relations between the subject and the object (5). :{| |(5) |''Na'' |''anakeda'' |''[na'' |''ma-'' |''ina'' |''-nya]'' |- | |ART |child |[ART |RmS- |mother |-3sD] |- | | colspan="6" |'the child whose mother she is'/'the child she is the mother of' |} The second clause type is where the possessor is the head of the ma- relative clause and the possessee is the subject of the embedded verb (6). :{| |(6) |''Ita'' |''-nggu'' |''-nya'' |''[na'' |''tau'' |''na'' |''ma-meti'' |''kuru uma'' |''-na]'' |- | |See |-1sG |-3sD |[ART |person |ART |RmS-die |wife |-3sG] |- | | colspan="9" |'I saw [the man whose wife died] |} The final type is where the relative clause contains the verb ''ningu'' ‘be’ and the incorporated argument of this verb. The head of the relative construction is the possessor (7). :{| |(7) |''Na'' |''tau'' |''na'' |''ma-'' |''ningu'' |''ihi'' |''woka'' |''.ng'' |- | |ART |person |ART |RmS- |be |content |garden |.ng |- | | colspan="8" |'the person that has crops' (lit.: 'the person whose garden content is') |} *N.B: the morpheme ''.ng'' marks the edge of incorporation Normally, the possessor pronoun ''nyuna'' ‘he/she’ follows the possessed noun (8), though it can also be the head of a relativised clause (9). :{| |(8) |''Na'' |''marihak'' |''[na'' |''kalembi'' |''-na'' |''nyuna]'' |- | |ART |be dirty |[ART |shirt |-3sG |he] |- | | colspan="6" |'His shirt is dirty' |} :{| |(9) |''Nyuna'' |''na'' |''[ma-'' |''marihak'' |''na'' |''kalembi'' |''-na'' |- | |He |ART |RmS- |be dirty |ART |shirt |-3sG |- | | colspan="7" |'He whose shirt is dirty' |} Possessors can also be relativised in the same way as subjects. For example, in the following headless relative clause (no possessor NP is present), a definite article is present (10). :{| |(10) |Na |ma- |rabih |karaha |kalai |-na |- | |ART |RmS- |trickle |side |left |-3sG |- | | colspan="6" |'The (one) whose left side trickles (i.e. lets water through)' (mythological character that is the source of rain) |} ==Footnotes== ==Bibliography== *{{cite book |last=Klamer |first=Marian |year=1998 |title=Kambera |location=Berlin/New York |publisher=Mouton de Gruyter}} *{{cite book |last=Klamer |first=Marian |year=2005 |chapter=Kambera |editor=Adelaar, Karl Alexander |editor2=Himmelmann, Nikolaus |title=The Austronesian Languages of Asia and Madagascar |location=London |publisher=Curzon Press}} *Klamer, Marian (1998) ''A Grammar of Kambera.'' '''Khodainazar Sarmachar''' ({{lang-bal|خداینظر سرمچار}}), was born 1955 in [[Nimruz Province]] and has a B.A. He was a member of the Committee on ''Health and Physical Education'' and ''International Relations Committee'' in [[Wolesi Jirga]] or Parliament of [[Afghanistan]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://areu.org.af/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/1042E-Governance-Structures-in-Nimroz-CS-2010-Web.pdf |format=PDF |title=Afghanistan Research and Evaluation Unit Case Study Series |website=Areu.org.af |accessdate=2017-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/80/Nimroz_Prov_Overview_CCS.pdf |title=People of Ghazni |format=PDF |website=Upload.wikimedia.org |date= |accessdate=2017-07-07}}</ref>. He is a former Governor of [[Nimruz province|Nimruz]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afghan-bios.info/index.php?option=com_afghanbios&id=1619&task=view&total=11&start=10&Itemid=2 |title=Database |website=Afghan-bios.info |date= |accessdate=2017-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://muqawamat.blogfa.com/post-2575.aspx |title=به وبلاک مقاومت خوش آمدید - خدای نظر سرمچار، نماینده مردم نیمروز: آزادی بیان همانند آن است که فریاد بکشی، اما چیزی نخواهی! |website=Muqawamat.blogfa.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-07}}</ref>
==Early years== Khodai nazar Sarmachar was born 1955 in [[Chakhansur District|Chekhansur]], [[Nimruz Province]]. He graduated in 1975 from the Farokhi High School in Nimroz. Sarmachar graduated in 1981 from Faculty of Veterinary Medicine from the [[Kabul University]] in Kabul.

{{Expand Spanish|Exposición Rural Argentina|date=July 2013}} [[File:Expos.rural_floridayparag_1875.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The first Rural Exhibition held in Buenos Aires, 1875.]]
'''''La Exposición Rural''''' (in English: The Rural Exhibition), is an annual [[agricultural show|agricultural and livestock show]] held in the [[Palermo, Buenos Aires|Palermo]] section of [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. The event is organised by ''La Sociedad Rural Argentina'' (in English: The Argentine Rural Society) and both the Exhibition and the Society are known locally as ''La Rural''.
The exhibition has taken place in the society's [[Santa Fe Avenue]] exhibition centre and fairground, each year in July since 1886. Primarily a farming show, breeders arrive from all over the country to exhibit their [[livestock]], particularly [[cattle]]. It became a major feature of the ''[[porteño]]'' social scene in prosperous Argentina, taking place in [[Buenos Aires]]' most exclusive neighbourhood and accompanied by [[Ball (dance)|ball]]s and other events. However, with the onset of the country's economic crisis towards the end of the 20th century, the event lost some of its vitality, although it is still popular with visitors. In 2005, 715,000 people visited the exhibition, which had almost 400 stands and 4,000 animals.
The Society was founded on 10 July 1866 by Eduardo Olivera and José Martínez de Hoz with the motto 'To cultivate the soil is to serve the country', and was formerly known as 'El Solar de Palermo'. Built in the 1870s, the Society's showground features a [[Belle Époque|Belle Epoque]] stadium and a modern exhibition hall. During the rest of the year, the exhibition hall is used for other events including [[trade show]]s. The ''Opera Pampa'' organises shows in the stadium, showcasing the [[history of Argentina]] with [[zamba (artform)|zamba]] dances and an ''[[asado]]'' in the dining rooms. With over 10,000 members, the Society has branch offices in many parts of the country.
[[File:Panoramica de La Rural (29-07-08) (GuiaMartinez).jpg|thumb|center|600px|Panoramic view of the Rural Exhibition]] ==External links== *[http://www.larural.com.ar/ Showground website (in Spanish)]

[[File:Cover Mavo n 3.jpg|thumb|Cover Mavo n 3]] [[File:MAVO Dance.jpg|thumb|MAVO Dance]]
'''MAVO''' was a radical Japanese art movement of the 1920s. Founded in 1923, as a re-institution of the Japanese Association of Futurist Artists, the anarchistic artist group displayed an outdoor exhibit in Ueno Park in Tokyo in protest of conservatism in the Japanese art world. The group leader was [[Tomoyoshi Murayama]] (1901 - 1977). The group deployed an interdisciplinary array of performance art, painting, illustration and architecture, to communicate anti-establishment messages to the mainstream. Fueled by responses to industrial development, the MAVO group created works about crisis, peril and uncertainty. Art Historian, [[Gennifer Weisenfeld]] has written that Mavo sought to reintegrate art into daily life. Other artists involved in the movement include [[Masamu Yanase]], [[Kamenosuke Ogata]], [[Shuzo Oura]] and [[Shinro Kadowaki]], and later [[Osamu Shibuya]], [[Shuichiro Kinoshita]], [[Iwane Sumiya]], [[Tatsuo Okada]], [[Michinao Takamizawa]], [[Kimimaro Yabashi]], [[Tatsuo Todai]], [[Masao Kato]] and [[Kyojiro Haiwara]], among others.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Weisenfeld|first1=Gennifer|title=Mavo: Japanese Artists and the Avant-Garde, 1905-1931|date=2002|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520223387|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520223387}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wang|first1=Yang|title=Russia Constructed: the Practice of Avant-gardism in Taisho-era Japan, 1912-1926|date=December 2009|url=https://kb.osu.edu/dspace/bitstream/1811/.../1/New_RU_JP_Hayes.pdf|website=osu.edu|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref>“Mavoist” artists sought to disrupt or blur the boundaries between art and daily life. They rebelled against the establishment by combining industrial products with painting or printmaking, usually in collage form. Their performance art protests against social injustice deployed theatrical eroticism, that mocked public norms for morality at the time.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Monskop.org|title=MAVO|url=http://monoskop.org/Mavo|website=Monoskop|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref>
==History==
During the 1923 demonstration, [[Takamizawa Michinao]], one of the members of MAVO, threw rocks in protest, through a glass ceiling of a building housing an exhibition of artworks curated by Nika-kai (The Second Society). Nika-kai was established in 1914 to oppose the conservative [[Bunten]], the governmental Ministry of Education Exhibition. Murayama had spent 1922 in Berlin where he became familiar with the social satire painting of [[Georg Grosz]], [[Wassily Kandinsky]]'s "spiritual" abstract paintings, [[El Lissitzky]]'s constructivist works, and [[Alexander Archipenko]]'s sculptures. As a cultural leader and public figure, Murayama had a confident, flamboyant personality, an androgynous physical presence sporting a bob-hairstyle, and posing for photographs in states of undress.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Larking|first1=Matthew|title=Mavo, the movement that rocked Japan’s art scene|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2012/04/26/arts/mavo-the-movement-that-rocked-japans-art-scene-2/#.VttW5ulE90A|accessdate=5 March 2016|publisher=The Japan Times|date=April 26, 2012}}</ref>
==Magazine==
Tatsuo Okada and Tomoyoshi Murayama edited MAVO magazine, that published seven issues between July 1924 and August 1925. The publication included essays on socio-cultural art, poetry, and theatrical texts. The pages included original linocut prints and photographic reproductions of visual art that often appropriated the work of their own members. Reuse and recycling from one project to another was one of the group's trademark strategies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gardner|first1=William|title=Poetry and New Media: An Essay on the 1920's Avant-garde, Focusing on Hagiwara Kyojiro's "Advertising Tower !" 詩と新メディア : 萩原恭次郎の｢広告塔！｣を中心にした一九二〇年代のアヴァンギャルド論考|journal=Comparative Literature and Culture|date=1999|issue=16}}</ref>
==Artists' books==
Several members of the group produced short-run artist's books including Hagiwara Kyojiro's ''Shikei senkoku'' (Death Sentence), an anthology of visual poetry published in 1925, and illustrated by MAVO; Ernst Toller's ''Tsubame no sho'', (The Swallow Book) illustrated by Tatsuo Okada and translated by Tomoyoshi Murayama (1925); and Hideo Saito's ''Aozameta douteikyo'', (The Pale-faced Virgin's Mad Thoughts) visual poetry published in 1926 and illustrated by Tatsuo Okada.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Weisenfeld|first1=Gennifer|title=Mavo's Conscious Constructivism: Art, Individualism, and Daily Life in Interwar Japan|journal=Art Journal|date=Autumn 1996|volume=55|issue=3|pages=64–73}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://hiroyasu-tangerine.blogspot.com/2010/11/mavo.html Mavo], Tangerine blog * [http://mavo.takekuma.jp/manga/memo/aboutmavo.html Denno Mavo] * [http://www.spencerart.ku.edu/collection/recent/tatsuo.shtml Okada Tatsuo], Spencer Museum of Art

[[Image:Men's Health Sept Cover.jpg|thumb|''[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]'' magazine, published by [[Rodale, Inc.|Rodale Press]]]] '''Medical journalism''' is news reporting (as opposed to peer-review publication) of medical news and features. Medical journalism is diverse, and reflects its audience. The main division is into (1) medical journalism for the general public, which includes medical coverage in general news publications and in specialty medical publications, and (2) medical journalism for doctors and other professionals, which often appears in peer-reviewed journals.<ref>[http://www.mjauk.org/about/ Medical Journalists' Association (UK)]</ref> The accuracy of medical journalism varies widely. Reviews of mass media publications have graded most stories unsatisfactory, although there were examples of excellence.<ref name="Schwitzer-JAMAIM">{{cite journal| title =A guide to reading health care news stories.| journal =JAMA Intern. Med. | date =Jul 2014| author =Schwitzer G.| volume =174| issue =7| pages =1183–6| url =https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/article-abstract/1867181| doi =10.1001/jamainternmed.2014.1359| pmid =24796314| pmc =}}</ref><ref name=Larsson/> Other reviews have found that most errors in mass media publications were the result of repeating errors in the original journal articles or their press releases.<ref name="Schwartz-BMJ">{{cite journal| title =Influence of medical journal press releases on the quality of associated newspaper coverage: retrospective cohort study.| journal =BMJ | date =Jan 27, 2012| vauthors =Schwartz LM, Woloshin S, Andrews A, Stukel TA| volume =344| pages =d8164| url =http://www.bmj.com/content/344/bmj.d8164.long| doi =10.1136/bmj.d8164 | pmid =22286507| pmc =3267473}}</ref> Some web sites, such as [[Columbia Journalism Review]] and [[Hippocrates Med Review]], publish and review medical journalism.
== Sources == Medical journalism can come from a variety of sources including: * Television news programs * Newspapers * Internet websites * Scientific journals (those that report health- and medical-related news)
== Accuracy ==
Most inaccuracies and speculations in news coverage can be attributed to several barriers between the scientific community and the general public that include lack of knowledge by reporters, lack of time to prepare a proper report, and lack of space in the publication.<ref name=Larsson>{{cite journal |vauthors=Larsson A, Oxman AD, Carling C, Herrin J |title= Medical messages in the media—barriers and solutions to improving medical journalism |journal= Health Expect |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=323–31 |year=2003 |pmid=15040794 |pmc= 5060204 |doi=10.1046/j.1369-7625.2003.00228.x}}</ref> Most news articles fail to discuss important issues such as evidence quality, costs, and risks versus benefits.<ref name=Schwitzer>{{cite journal |author= Schwitzer G |title= How Do US Journalists Cover Treatments, Tests, Products, and Procedures? An Evaluation of 500 Stories |journal= PLoS Med |volume=5 |issue=5 |pages=e95 |year=2008 |pmid=18507496 |doi=10.1371/journal.pmed.0050095 |url=http://journals.plos.org/plosmedicine/article?id=10.1371/journal.pmed.0050095 |laysummary=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/jun/21/2 |laysource=Guardian |laydate=2008-06-21 |pmc= 2689661}}</ref> However, medical journalism is not only what is being commercialized and covered by news and mass media. There is also another extensive, more academic branch of medical journalism which is based on evidence. Evidence-based research is more accurate and thus it is a much more reliable source than medical news disseminated by tabloids. Medical journalism in this regard is a professional field and is often disregarded. There are also some medical journalism institutions that provide assistance to medical researchers to enable them to perform more reliable studies. A 2009 study found small improvements in some areas of medical reporting in Australia, but the overall quality remained poor, particularly in commercial human-interest television programs.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors= Wilson A, Bonevski B, Jones A, Henry D |title= Media Reporting of Health Interventions: Signs of Improvement, but Major Problems Persist |journal= PLoS ONE |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=e4831 |year=2009 |pmid=19293924 |pmc=2652829 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0004831 |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0004831 |editor1-last= Gluud |editor1-first= Lise Lotte}}</ref>
More recently, the use of [[Medical writing|medical writers]] has become more popular as a way to produce medical literature that is clear, concise, and easier to read by the lay person.
The [http://www.icmje.org/ ICMJE], International Committee of Medical Journal Editors, is a committee that specifically deals with this kind of issue. This organization is committed to keeping medical reporting as true as possible by setting a standard known as URM, or the Uniform Requirements for Manuscripts. These requirements do not only specify technical points such as bibliographical references and copyrights but also regarding ethical issues that may arise. For example, a submitter must disclose any personal or professional relationships that might even slightly have a bearing on the submitted work.
To this end, it is not uncommon for researchers to hold a press conference or interviews before publishing significant research to prevent any misconstruing of any data or methods.<ref>{{cite web|title=ICMJE Uniform Requirements of Manuscripts|url=http://www.icmje.org/publishing_9media.html|publisher=International Committee of Medical Journal Editors|accessdate=12 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111091852/http://www.icmje.org/publishing_9media.html|archivedate=11 November 2012|df=}}</ref>
== Conflict of interest ==
===Between scientists and journalists=== A large gap divides the scientific and journalist communities when it comes to deciding what is newsworthy. The ongoing nature of peer review in the scientific community makes it difficult to report interesting advances in scientific discovery. Consequently, this can create a focus on the negative aspects of medicine and science; causing journalists to report on the mistakes of doctors or misconstruing the results of research. However, journalists are not the only ones to fault as scientists have also broadcast their promising initial research to the media in attempts to secure future funding.<ref name=Nelkin>{{cite journal|last=Nelkin|first=Dorothy|title=An Uneasy Relationship: The Tensions between Medicine and the Media.|journal=Lancet|date=June 1996|volume=347|issue=1905|pages=1600–1603|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(96)91081-8}}</ref> For example, research done by George Washington University in 1993 on in-vitro fertilization was warped by the media into a horrific foray into human cloning.
===Due to corporate influence=== Medical journalists also face challenges due to potential conflicts of interest. The pharmaceutical industry has sponsored journalism contests that carry large prizes in cash or in overseas trips. The [[Association of Health Care Journalists]] (AHCJ) urges journalists to consider these contests carefully before entering, and most journalists avoid them. The Center for Excellence in Health Care Journalism, the supporting 501(c)(3) for AHCJ, does not accept industry funding. The [[National Association of Science Writers]] does not accept such funding. The changing nature of news media has caused more reporters to work freelance, outside of traditional news organizations such as major metropolitan newspapers, which may have created more ways to sidestep conflict-of-interest standards, and the rise of blogs has allowed nontraditional providers of news that lack these standards entirely.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Greene J |title= Pharma's influence on the fourth estate: health care journalists' conflicts also scrutinized |journal= Ann Emerg Med |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=18A–20A |year=2009 |pmid=19244660 |doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2009.01.010}}</ref>
There is also the effect of direct corporate investments in research funding. While appreciated by scientists, this may cause conflicts with journalists that see this as profiteering.<ref name=Nelkin/>
== Reviews ==
Sources for evaluating health care media coverage include the review websites Behind the Headlines, [[Health News Review]], and Media Doctor (see ''[[#External links|External links]]''), along with specialized academic journals such as the ''Journal of Health Communication''. Reviews can also appear in the ''[[American Journal of Public Health]]'', the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', [[Ben Goldacre]]'s "Bad Science" column in ''[[The Guardian]]'', and others. Health News Review has published criteria for rating news stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://healthnewsreview.org/how_we_rate.php |accessdate=2009-03-26 |year=2008 |publisher=Health News Review |title=How we rate stories |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090110012618/http://www.healthnewsreview.org/how_we_rate.php |archivedate=January 10, 2009 }}</ref>
== Effects on the general public == Although medical news articles often deliver public health messages effectively, they often convey wrong or misleading information about health care, partly when reporters do not know or cannot convey the results of clinical studies, and partly when they fail to supply reasonable context.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Dentzer S |title= Communicating medical news—pitfalls of health care journalism |journal= N Engl J Med |volume=360 |issue=1 |pages=1–3 |year=2009 |pmid=19118299 |doi=10.1056/NEJMp0805753 |url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/360/1/1}}</ref> This can result in unrealistic expectations due to coverage of radical medical procedures and experimental technology.<ref name=Larsson/> Mass media news outlets can also create a "communications storm" to shift attention to a single health issue.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Carducci|first=Annalaura|author2=Simona Alfani|title=Mass media health information: Quantitative and qualitative analysis of daily press coverage and its relation with public perceptions|journal=Patient Education and Counseling|year=2011|volume=82|issue=3|pages=475–478|doi=10.1016/j.pec.2010.12.025}}</ref> The lack of health knowledge in the general public creates a situation where a person can be easily swayed to a certain point of view that is cast in the manner in which information is reported. Consequently, this can create a potentially unhealthy focus on an illness that in actuality is relatively rare.
Medical journalism can also influence an individual's quality of health care. Due to the relative ease at which information can be obtained on the internet, many people will now question doctors on new medications and treatments for their conditions. In more extreme cases, people will compare their symptoms, real or imagined, to various illnesses in attempts to diagnose themselves.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Suziedelyte|first=Agne|title=How does searching for health information on the Internet affect individuals' demand for health care services?|journal=Social Science & Medicine|date=August 2012|volume=75|issue=10|pages=1828–1835|doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2012.07.022}}</ref> There have been a few recent studies that have tried to explore the availability of health information as complement to health care or as a substitute yet no direct relationships have been found. This is most likely caused by a lack of knowledge or a lack of the ability in the individual to apply the health information once found resulting in seeking health care.
== Training == Only a handful of universities and institutes globally offer undergraduate, postgraduate or diploma level programs related to medical journalism. The University of Westminster, UK conducts a BA Honors in Medical Journalism.<ref>{{cite web|title=University of Westminster Website|url=http://www.westminster.ac.uk/courses/subjects/journalism-and-mass-communication/undergraduate-courses/full-time/d09fumej-ba-honours-medical-journalism|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> In the US, Boston University via its College of Communication conducts a Science and Medical Journalism program leading to a Master's of Science Degree.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boston University Website|url=http://www.bu.edu/com/academics/journalism/graduate/science-journalism/curriculum/|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref> For those looking for an online mode of education, the James Lind Institute conducts Diploma and Advanced Diploma programs related to Scientific Writing and Medical Journalism.<ref>{{cite web|title=James Lind Institute Website|url=http://www.jli.edu.in/diploma_sw_mj.php|accessdate=23 February 2015}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Medical writing]] * [[Science by press conference]] * [[Social determinants of health]]
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == * [http://mediadoctor.org.au/ Media Doctor] (Australia) * [http://www.nhs.uk/News Behind the Headlines] (UK) * [http://healthnewsreview.org/ Health News Review] (U.S.) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091007081641/http://www.bazian.com/pdfs/HowToReadANewsStory_vers03_26Nov08.pdf How to Read Articles about Health and Healthcare] by Alicia White * [http://www.mjauk.org/ Medical Journalists' Association] (UK)

{{Infobox language |name=Naruo |altname= |nativename= |states=[[China]] |ethnicity=[[Yi people|Yi]] |speakers=15,000 |date=2007 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam2=([[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]]) |fam3=[[Lolo–Burmese languages|Lolo–Burmese]] |fam4=[[Loloish languages|Loloish]] |fam5=[[Lisoish languages|Lisoish]] |fam6=[[Taloid languages|Taloid]] |iso3=ylo |glotto=nalu1239 |glottorefname=Naluo Yi }}
'''Naruo 纳若''' (Naluo 纳罗, Laluo; also Alu, Gan Yi) is a [[Loloish languages|Loloish]] [[language cluster]] spoken by the [[Yi people]] of [[Yunnan]], [[China]].
==Classification== ''Naluo'' is classified by ''Ethnologue'' as a [[Northern Loloish languages|Northern Loloish]] language, but Yang, et al. (2017)<ref name="Yang2017">Yang, Cathryn; Kwok Wailing 范秀琳 Zhou Decai 周德才; Yang Wenjing 杨文静. 2017. ''The Taloid Cluster of Northwestern Yunnan: Loyal Soldiers of the Nanzhao Kingdom'' / 滇西北彝语他留土群：忠诚的南诏战士. Presented at ICSTLL 50, Beijing, China.</ref> classifies ''Naruo'' as a [[Taloid languages|Taloid]] language.
==Demographics== According to David Bradley (2004),<ref name="Bradley2004">Bradley, David. 2004. ''[https://www.academia.edu/5737342/Endangered_Central_Ngwi_Languages_of_Central_Yunnan Endangered Central Ngwi Languages of Central Yunnan]''. Keynote Presentation, 37th International Conference on Sino-Tibetan Languages and Linguistics, Lund University, Sweden.</ref> Naluo (Naruo, Laluo, Naru, Shuitian 水田, Shui Yi 水彝 (used in Yunnan)) is spoken by about 15,000 people mostly in eastern [[Yongsheng County]] and southern [[Huaping County]], Yunnan, as well as in Pingjiang 平江 and Futian 福田镇 townships, western [[Panzhihua]] City, Sichuan. Naluo is moribund or extinct in Sichuan, and endangered in Yunnan.
==Varieties== You (2013:85)<ref name="You2013">You Weiqiong [尤伟琼]. 2013. ''Classifying ethnic groups of Yunnan'' [云南民族识别研究]. Beijing: Ethnic Publishing House [民族出版社].</ref> reports that the ''na21 zu21''<ref>[http://www.doc88.com/p-97281176367.html 云南民族识别参考资料] (1955), p.22</ref> (Naruo 纳儒) language is spoken by the following Yi subgroups. *'''Zhili 支里''' ([[Exonym and endonym|autonym]]: '''Naruo 纳儒'''): Nanhua Township, District 1, [[Yongsheng County]] 永胜县一区南华乡 *'''Luo 倮族''' (autonym: '''Naruo 纳儒'''): Zhongcheng Township, District 4, Yongsheng County 永胜县四区忠诚乡 *'''Zi Yi 子彝''' (autonym: '''Naruo 纳儒'''): Xilang Township, District 3, Yongsheng County 永胜县三区习朗乡
On the other hand, the ''Yongsheng County Almanac'' (1989:637) lists the following subgroups within Shuitian 水田. *'''Shuitian 水田''' (autonym: '''Naru 纳儒''') *'''Shui Yi 水彝''' subgroup (autonym: '''Naruo 纳若''') *'''Luoluo 倮倮''' subgroup (autonym: '''Xiqima 洗期麻'''; also called '''Li 傈/黎''')
Other varieties are:<ref>https://asiaharvest.org/people-group-profiles/#china</ref> *'''Naru 纳儒''' of southern and central [[Yongsheng County]] (pop. 7,000) and southern [[Huaping County]] (pop. 4,500) *'''Naruo 纳若''' (Zhili) of [[Yongsheng County]] and [[Huaping County]], spoken by about 12,000 people. It may be the same as Xiaoliangshan Nosu.
'''Lopi (Shuitian 水田)'''<ref>http://asiaharvest.org/wp-content/themes/asia/docs/people-groups/China/chinaPeoples/L/Lopi.pdf</ref> is an essentially extinct language, although there are more than 15,000 people belonging to the ethnic group in [[Panzhihua]], Sichuan (in Futian 福田 and Pingjiang 平江 Townships) and in northern Yunnan.
Yang, et al. (2017)<ref name="Yang2017">Yang, Cathryn; Kwok Wailing 范秀琳 Zhou Decai 周德才; Yang Wenjing 杨文静. 2017. ''The Taloid Cluster of Northwestern Yunnan: Loyal Soldiers of the Nanzhao Kingdom'' / 滇西北彝语他留土群：忠诚的南诏战士. Presented at ICSTLL 50, Beijing, China.</ref> lists '''[[Popei language|Popei]] 泼佩''' and '''Naruo 纳若''' as Shuitian 水田 varieties, and classifies them as part of the [[Taloid languages|Taloid]] cluster of [[Lisoish languages|Central Ngwi languages]].
'''Zhili 支里''' (autonym: '''Naruo 那若''') is spoken by more than 300 persons in Xinying Village 新营村, Nanhua Township 南华乡, Beisheng District 北胜区<ref>http://www.ynszxc.gov.cn/villagePage/vIndex.aspx?departmentid=105512</ref>; and in Xianrenhe Village 仙人河村, Dachang Township 大厂乡<ref>http://www.ynszxc.gov.cn/villagePage/vdefault.aspx?departmentid=105563</ref> (''Yongsheng County Almanac '' 1989:637).

{{Italic title}} '''''Nongoloza's Children: Western Cape Prison Gangs During and After Apartheid''''', a book written as a monograph about the gangs from prisons of the [[Western Cape]] during and after [[Racial integration|racial isolation]], was written for the Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation by [[Jonny Steinberg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csvr.org.za/docs/gangs/nongolozaschildren.pdf|title=Nongoloza's Children: Western Cape prison gangs during and after apartheid|author=Jonny Steinberg|website=Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation| page=1}}</ref><ref name="Center for Security Studies">{{cite web|url=http://www.css.ethz.ch/en/services/digital-library/publications/publication.html/99648 |title=Nongoloza's Children |date=July 2004 |website=Center for Security Studies, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich |accessdate=May 2, 2017}}</ref> It explores the prevalence of gangs in society and in prisons and offers recommendations for solving post-[[apartheid]] [[gang violence]].<ref name="Center for Security Studies" />
==Overview== The author writes that he spent nine months of research at PollsMoor Prison Admission Center. There he interviewed the prisoners, most of whom were awaiting trial. For an 18-month period he interviewed about 30 veterans members of gangs. During the 1980s and 1990s all of them served their sentences in prisons throughout the Western Cape.<ref name="Make this up">{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/17533171.2011.642586 | volume=13 | title="In a Country where You couldn't Make this Shit up"?: Literary Non‐Fiction in South Africa | year=2012 | journal=Safundi | pages=5–28 | author=Twidle Hedley}}</ref><ref name="TandF">{{cite journal|doi=10.1080/10246029.2005.9627345 | volume=14 | title=BOOK REVIEWS | journal=African Security Review | pages=135–143 | year=2005 | author=Altbeker Antony}}</ref>
According to Steinberg, [[The Numbers Gang]]s take their inspiration from the historical figure Nongoloza Mathebula, born Mzuzephi Mathebula, who became the founder of The Number Gangs in South Africa. An early Johannesburg bandit, he built a quasi-military band of outlaws, welding his small army together with a simple but potent ideology of banditry-as-anti-colonial-resistance.<ref name="Make this up" /><ref name="TandF" />
== About the author ==
Jonny Steinberg – is a writer, scholar and a professor of African Studies that joined the African Studies Center in October 2011. Was born in March 22, 1970 (47 y.o.) in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]].<ref name="africanstudies.ox.ac.uk">[http://www.africanstudies.ox.ac.uk/ African Studies Centre. School of interdisciplinary area studies]</ref>
He is an author of several books about day-to-day life in the wake of South Africa's transition to democracy. Much of his work explores people that live in South Africa and prisons, police, clinics and farms in this conditions.<ref name="africanstudies.ox.ac.uk"/>

{{For|the American fisherman and television presenter|Orlando Wilson (television presenter)}} {{Infobox person | name = Orlando Winfield Wilson | birth_date = {{Birth date|1900|5|15}} | image = | birth_place = [[Veblen, South Dakota]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1972|10|18|1900|5|15}} | death_place = [[Poway, California]], U.S. | known_for = | occupation = {{hlist|Police superintendent|author}} | residence = | education = | employer = [[Chicago Police Department]] | title = Superintendent
(1960–1967) |yearsactive = 1925–1967 | salary = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = United States of America | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1939–1947 | rank = [[Sergeant#United States|Sergeant]] | unit = | battles = [[World War II]] | awards = }} }} '''Orlando Winfield Wilson''' (May 15, 1900 – October 18, 1972), also known as '''O. W. Wilson''', was an American police officer, later becoming a leader in [[policing]]. Wilson served as Superintendent of Police for the [[Chicago Police Department]] under the [[Richard J. Daley]] administration from 1960 until retiring in 1967. [[chief of police]] in [[Fullerton, California]] and [[Wichita, Kansas]], and authored several books on policing. ==Background== ===Early life and career=== Wilson was born on May 15, 1900, in [[Veblen, South Dakota]], and moved with his family to California.{{cite book |title=Police An Introduction |author=Lyman, Michael D. |year=2004 |publisher=Prentice Hall |isbn=978-0-13-118222-6}} In 1921, Wilson enrolled in the [[University of California, Berkeley]], majoring in [[criminology]] and studying under [[August Vollmer]]. Wilson graduated in 1924, with a Bachelor of Arts degree.{{cite web |url=http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=tf3v19n6s0&doc.view=entire_text |title=Guide to the Orlando Winfield Wilson Papers, ca. 1928–1972 |publisher=Online Archive of California |accessdate=2006-10-20}} While at Berkeley, he also worked as a [[police officer]] with the [[Berkeley Police Department]]; such education for a [[police officer]] was rare at the time.{{cite book |title=Security and Crime Prevention |author=[[Joseph Donnermeyer|Donnermeyer, Joseph F.]], Robert L. O'Block |year=1991 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=978-0-7506-9007-2}} During World War II, Wilson served as a Provost Marshal with the U.S. Army and retired from the service with the rank of full colonel in the military police. Wilson remained in Europe until 1947 as an advisor to local law enforcement. ===Policing=== In 1925, Wilson became chief of police of the [[Fullerton Police Department]] for two years. He then spent two years as an investigator with the Pacific Finance Corporation. In 1928, at age 28, he became chief of police of the [[Wichita Police Department]], where he served until 1939. In Wichita, he led reforms to reduce [[Police corruption|corruption]]. There he instituted professionalism in the department, requiring new hires to have a [[college]] education, and introduced innovations, such as the use [[police car]]s for patrol, mobile [[radio]]s, and use of a mobile [[crime laboratory]]. He believed that use of [[two-way radio]] allowed for better supervision of patrol officers, and therefore more efficient policing. When the war ended, he remained in Europe until 1947, leading reorganization of police forces in Europe.{{cite book |author=Russell, Gregory D., Terry Gingerich, Rebecca Paynich, James A Conser |title=Law Enforcement in the United States |publisher=Jones and Bartlett Publishers |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-7637-8352-5}} ===Chicago=== In 1960, [[Chicago]] mayor [[Richard J. Daley]], in the wake of a major police [[scandal]],{{cite book |title=Crime and Punishment in American History |author=Friedman, Lawrence M. |year=1993 |publisher=Basic Books |isbn=978-0-465-01461-3}} established a commission headed by Wilson to find a new police commissioner.{{cite news |title=Police Head Resigns in Chicago After Stratton Bids Mayor Act |publisher=Associated Press/The New York Times |date=January 24, 1960}} In the end, Daley decided to appoint Wilson himself, as Commissioner.{{cite news |title=Chicago Chooses Criminologist to Head and Clean Up the Police |publisher=United Press International/The New York Times |date=February 22, 1960}} Beginning on March 2, 1960, Wilson served the Superintendent of Police of the [[Chicago Police Department]] until 1967 when he retired. Reforms demanded at the outset by Wilson included establishment of a non-partisan police board to help govern the police force, a strict [[:wikt:merit|merit]] system for promotions within the department, an aggressive, nationwide recruiting drive for hiring new officers, and higher police salaries to attract professionally qualified officers. For starters, Wilson moved the superintendent's office from City Hall to Police Headquarters and closed police districts and redrew their boundaries without regard to politics. Hiring standards were raised, graft curbed, and discipline tightened, with a new Police Board overseeing it. Wilson updated the communications system, adopted computers and improved record-keeping, bought new squad cars, and eliminated most foot patrols. Police boasted of quicker response times to citizen calls. Police morale, and the public image of the police, rose. Wilson also improved police relations with the black community. He recruited more African American officers, promoted black sergeants, and insisted on police restraint in racially charged conflicts.{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/983.html |title=Police|publisher=Encyclopedia of Chicago |accessdate=2007-04-14}} ===Academia=== Wilson had also taught at [[Harvard University]] in the 1930s, working with the Harvard Bureau for Street Traffic Research.{{cite news |title=Law Enforcement Held Safety Need |author=Halsey, Maxwell |date=November 11, 1936 |publisher=The New York Times}} He also served as director of the New England Traffic Officers' Training School, which offered intensive two-week courses to police officers on [[traffic]] safety and enforcement. In 1939, Wilson became Professor of Police Administration at Berkeley.{{cite web |url=http://www.cmsu.edu/x74741.xml |title=O.W. Wilson |publisher=University of Central Missouri |accessdate=2006-10-20}} From 1950 to 1960, Wilson was the [[Dean (education)|dean]] of Berkeley's School of Criminology. Wilson authored several books, including ''Police Records'', ''Police Planning'', and the highly influential work, ''Police Administration'' which was first published in 1943. While at Berkeley, Wilson also served as a consultant, advising cities including [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], and [[Louisville, Kentucky]] on reorganization of their police agencies. ==Police professionalism== By the 1950s, Wilson's ideas of police professionalism, presented in ''Police Administration'', were widely implemented in police agencies across the [[United States]].{{cite book |title=Police Innovation: Contrasting Perspectives |author=Weisburd, David, Anthony A. Braga |year=2006 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-83628-9}} These ideas remained popular until the advent of [[community policing]].{{cite book |title=Law Enforcement Information Technology: A Managerial, Operational, and Practitioner Guide |author=Chu, James |year=2001 |publisher=CRC Press |isbn=978-0-8493-1089-8}} Wilson believed that preventive [[patrol]] and rapid response to calls would be effective, creating a sense of police omnipresence among [[criminal]]s. ==Personal and death== Wilson, together with his wife Ruth Elinor Wilson, had one daughter.{{cite news |title=Educator on a New Beat |publisher=The New York Times |date=March 2, 1960}} Wilson had another son and daughter, by a previous marriage. After retiring from the Chicago Police Department in 1967, Wilson lived in [[Poway, California]] until his death in 1972. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/tf3v19n6s0/ Guide to the Orlando Winfield Wilson Papers] at [[The Bancroft Library]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilson, Orlando Winfield}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:American criminologists]] [[Category:American legal scholars]] [[Category:American municipal police officers]] [[Category:American police chiefs]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:Superintendents of the Chicago Police Department]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:People from Veblen, South Dakota]]

page.title: OIE/FAO Network of Expertise on Animal Influenza

revision.comment: sp.: [[World Health Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{advert|date=January 2011}} '''OFFLU''' is the joint '''O'''IE-'''F'''AO global network of expertise on animal in'''flu'''enzas. OFFLU aims to reduce negative impacts of animal [[influenza virus]]es by promoting effective collaboration between [[animal health]] experts and with the human health sector. OFFLU puts a strong emphasis on the importance of analysing and sharing information, and biological material to identify and reduce health threats early, and on sharing information about animal influenza viruses with the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) to assist with the early preparation of human vaccines. Since its establishment in 2005, initially to support the global effort to control [[H5N1]] highly pathogenic avian influenza, OFFLU has become a strong and functional network. The technical contribution to OFFLU is provided by an open network of world leading experts. This includes animal influenza experts from the OIE and FAO Reference Laboratories and Collaborating Centres, and from other institutes with leading expertise in diagnostics, epidemiology, bioinformatics, vaccinology, and animal production. Under the coordination and management of OFFLU, experts work together in discussion groups, called OFFLU Technical Activities, on pertinent topics and on technical projects to provide concrete outputs on relevant influenza related issues. To date, these Technical Activities have delivered guidance on diagnostic protocols, antigenic matching of vaccine strains with circulating field viruses, minimum biosafety guidelines for laboratory workers, and strategic guidance on animal influenza surveillance. The effectiveness and degree of collaboration between OFFLU and the human health sector (WHO) has improved significantly. This was highlighted following the emergence of pandemic H1N1 in April 2009 when OFFLU rapidly mobilised its experts to address the human-animal interface aspects of pandemic H1N1 jointly with colleagues from the public health sector. OFFLU continues to develop in terms of scope and geographical representation, and is looking ahead to developing a sustainable and effective mechanism for monitoring influenza viruses in animals and for communicating significant findings to all partners quickly. ==OFFLU's Objectives== • To share and offer technical advice, training and veterinary expertise to international organisations and Member Countries to assist in the prevention, diagnosis, surveillance and control of animal influenza.
• To exchange scientific data and biological materials (including virus strains) within the network, to analyse such data, and to share such information with the wider scientific community.
• To collaborate with the WHO on issues relating to the animal-human interface, including pandemic preparedness for early preparation of human vaccine.
• To highlight influenza surveillance and research needs, promote their development and ensure co-ordination. ''Structure''
The OFFLU network is managed by a steering committee who provide strategic direction, an Executive Committee who implement the decisions of the steering committee, a secretariat, and a dedicated OFFLU scientist. The network itself is made up of world leading scientists from a range of fields including virology, epidemiology, bioinformatics, vaccinology, and animal production. ==Origins== In February 2006, "OFFLU launched a campaign for openness when Dr. Ilaria Capua of Italy, chair of the network's Scientific Committee, published sequence data on H5N1 strains from Nigeria and Italy and urged 50 colleagues around the world to share their data. In March, the OFFLU Scientific Committee decided "to put new emphasis on the need for further collection, characterization, and exchange" of avian flu viruses and for expansion of sequence data, the FAO reported. At about the same time, Capua and four OFFLU colleagues wrote a letter to the journal Science promising to make H5N1 samples available for sequencing."[http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/influenza/avianflu/news/aug0306sharing.html CIDRAP] article ''Indonesia, FAO, OIE pledge to publish H5N1 data'' published August 3, 2006 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *[https://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol12no08/06-0380.htm CDC] article ''OFFLU Network on Avian Influenza'' detailing OFFLU "achievements and constraints to date and plans for the future". ==External links== {{Official website|www.offlu.net}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oie Fao Network Of Expertise On Animal Influenza}} [[Category:Animal disease control]] [[Category:Avian influenza]] [[Category:Epidemiology]] [[Category:Food and Agriculture Organization]] [[Category:Pandemics]]

{{About|the chemist||Paul Kirk (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Paul L. Kirk | image = Mgm_Paul_L_Kirk.png | image_size = 180px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1902|5|9|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[File:Flag of the United States.svg|25px|Country flag]] [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1970|6|5|1902|5|9}}<ref name="natcyc">{{cite encyclopedia | title = Paul Leland Kirk | encyclopedia = The National Cyclopedia of American Biographies | volume = 56 | pages = 490–491 | publisher = James T. White & Company | year = 1975 | location = Clifton, New Jersey }}</ref> | death_place = [[File:Flag of the United States.svg|25px|Country flag]] [[Alameda, California]]<ref name="MSU">[http://www.chemistry.msu.edu/Genealogy/work-area-K.shtml U.S. Social Security Death Index information] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060918010502/https://www.chemistry.msu.edu/Genealogy/work-area-K.shtml |date=2006-09-18 }} from Michigan State University website (Retrieved March 11, 2007).</ref> | occupation = Chemist, forensic scientist | spouse = | parents = | children = }}
{{Spoken Wikipedia|Paul_Kirk.ogg|2007-03-14}} '''Paul Leland Kirk''' (May 9, 1902 – June 5, 1970<ref name="natcyc"/><ref name="MSU"/>) was a [[chemist]], [[forensic science|forensic scientist]] and participant in the [[Manhattan Project]] who was specialized in [[microscopy]]. He also investigated the bedroom in which Sam Sheppard supposedly murdered his wife and provided the key [[bloodstain pattern analysis|blood spatter evidence]] that led to his [[acquittal]] in a retrial over 12 years after the murder. The highest honor one can receive in the [[criminalistics]] section of the [[American Academy of Forensic Sciences]] carries Kirk's name.<ref name="chisum"> {{cite book | last =Chisum | first =W. Jerry | authorlink = |author2=Brent E. Turvey | title = Crime Reconstruction | publisher = Academic Press | date = October 27, 2006 | location = | pages = 28–33 | chapter = Chapter 1: A History of Crime Reconstruction | chapterurl = http://books.elsevier.com/bookscat/samples/9780123693754/Sample_Chapters/02~chapter_1.pdf | doi = | isbn = 978-0-12-369375-4 | accessdate = 2007-03-08}}</ref>
==Education== Kirk received his [[Bachelor's degree]] in chemistry from [[Ohio State University]] and got his [[Masters degree]] in chemistry from the [[University of Pittsburgh]].<ref name="chisum"/> He went on to receive a [[Ph.D.]] in [[biochemistry]] from [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]].<ref name='sheppard-testimony'>{{cite web |url=http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/sheppard/kirktestimony.html |title=Selected Testimony of Doctor Paul Kirk in Sam Sheppard's 1966 Murder Trial |accessdate=2007-03-18 |publisher=[[University of Missouri-Kansas City]] School of Law |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416191653/http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/sheppard/kirktestimony.html |archive-date=2007-04-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}; taken from: Paul Holmes, Retrial: Murder and Dr. Sam Sheppard (1966)</ref>
==Career== In 1929 Kirk became professor of biochemistry at UC Berkeley. According to Kirk, he first became interested in forensic science in his early days as a teacher after a student asked if it could be determined if a dog had died of [[poison]]ing. Forensic science permanently piqued his interest when authorities asked him to do a microscopic examination of a rape victim's clothing. He found fibers from the attacker's shirt and this evidence resulted in a conviction. In 1937, Kirk became leader of UC Berkeley's [[criminology]] program. Due to his extensive experience in microscopy, Kirk was asked to join the [[Manhattan Project]] where he worked on the process to isolate [[Nuclear fission|fissionable]] [[plutonium]] from 1942 to 1945. When he returned to Berkeley, he created a major in technical criminology and when [[August Vollmer]] established the UC School of Criminology, Kirk was appointed to chair the criminalistics department.<ref name="chisum"/>
Kirk was also an avid supporter of [[Locard's exchange principle]]. As a result of his detailed descriptions of the principle, Kirk's words have repeatedly been mistaken for those of [[Edmond Locard]] himself. Unlike others before him, Kirk understood the limits of the principle and argued for caution in the interpretation of exchange evidence.<ref name="chisum"/>
Kirk is best known for his work in the [[Sam Sheppard]] case. On January 22, 1955 – one month after Sheppard's conviction – Kirk visited the scene of the crime after which he wrote an extensive report primarily based on [[bloodstain pattern analysis]]. A motion for a retrial had been denied in 1955, but this decision was overturned in 1964 and in 1966, the [[United States Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] upheld the decision for a retrial. Later that same year, Kirk testified at the retrial, which led to Sheppard's acquittal. Kirk's testimony embarrassed [[Samuel Gerber]], a senior member of the [[American Academy of Forensic Sciences]] (AAFS) who was working for the prosecution and believed in Sheppard's guilt. Kirk was denied AAFS membership, but he still left his mark on the organization. The highest honor awarded in the [[criminalistics]] section of the AAFS is the Paul L. Kirk Award.<ref name="chisum"/>
Dr. Kirk's photographs, analysis, and testimony from the Sam Sheppard case can be seen at http://engagedscholarship.csuohio.edu/kirk_photos/index.2.html.
==Bibliography== Not only did Kirk publish around 250 articles in multiple fields of research ranging from biochemistry to criminalistics; he also contributed articles to the [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] and he was the author of the following books.<ref name="natcyc"/> *''Quantitative Ultramicroanalysis'' (1950) *''Density and Refrective Index: Their Applications in Criminal Identification'' (1951) *''Crime Investigation: Physical Evidence and the Police Laboratory Interscience'' (1953)<ref name="fire-investigation">{{cite book | title=Fire Investigation (4th edition)| last=DeHaan| first=John D.| authorlink=John D. DeHaan|author2=Paul Leland Kirk | year=1996| pages=flap| publisher=Prentice Hall Health| isbn=978-0-8359-5056-5 }}</ref> *''[[Kirk's Fire Investigation|Fire Investigation]]'' (1969)<ref name="fire-investigation"/> *''The Crime Laboratory'' (1965), co-written with [[Lowell W. Bradford]]
==References== <references/>
{{Authority control}}

'''Qawm''' is a basic social unit of [[Afghanistan]] that is based on kinship, residence, or occupation.<ref>[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0IBS/is_1_28/ai_82351490 www.findarticles.com]</ref> It is sometimes translated as "tribe", but the qawm relationship may cross tribal or even ethnic boundaries.
The protean word ''qawm'' is of [[Arabic language|Arabic]] origin, and is used in Afghanistan to refer to any form of solidarity. [[Afghan|Afghans]] identify themselves by qawm, rather than by tribe or nationality. Qawm identity has added to the challenge of creating a national identity in Afghanistan. A qawm is typically governed by a [[jirga]] or [[shura]] (a council or assembly of elder males).
==See also== *[[Ethnic groups in Afghanistan]] *[[Qaum]]
