{{About|a term used in [[auto racing]]}} {{refimprove|date=February 2015}} [[Image:Mansell and Senna at Silverstone.jpg|thumb|right|[[Nigel Mansell]] gives [[Ayrton Senna]] a lift back to the pits on his victory lap after winning the [[1991 British Grand Prix]].]] [[File:2015 Punta del Este ePrix - Videos - Victory lap.webm|thumb|Victory lap at the 2015 Punta del Este ePrix]]
A '''victory lap''' (also '''lap of honor''') is a term used in [[motorsports]] to describe an extra lap of the [[race track]] after the conclusion of a [[Racing|race]]. This lap, driven at reduced speed, allows the winning driver to celebrate their victory and gives the spectators an opportunity to congratulate and honor the competitors. Commonly, trackside flag [[marshals]] will wave their [[racing flags|flags]] in a gesture known as the '''[[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] salute''' or the ''Monkey Dance'' in the US.{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} It is not uncommon for marshals to clap or wave their hands at drivers as a gesture and sometimes the drivers wave back in response.
Victory laps can sometime become dangerous for the winner and the other drivers, since in many tracks the safety nets can be easily climbed over by the crowd, which then becomes an obstacle for the racers.
Victory laps have regularly seen drivers who have retired in the final stages of a race being given a lift back to the pits on one of their competitors' cars. Some notable examples in [[Formula One]] include [[Riccardo Patrese]] and [[Didier Pironi]] at the [[1982 Monaco Grand Prix]], [[Nigel Mansell]] and [[Ayrton Senna]] at the [[1991 British Grand Prix]] (pictured), [[Jean Alesi]] and [[Michael Schumacher]] at the [[1995 Canadian Grand Prix]], Michael Schumacher and [[Giancarlo Fisichella]] at the [[1997 German Grand Prix]], [[Mika Häkkinen]] and [[David Coulthard]] at the [[2001 Spanish Grand Prix]], and [[Mark Webber]] and [[Fernando Alonso]] at the [[2011 German Grand Prix]] and [[2013 Singapore Grand Prix]]
Recently the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]], motor sport's world governing body, have restricted what a Formula One driver may do on his victory lap. The sporting regulations state that at the end of a race, "all cars must proceed on the circuit directly to the post race parc fermé without stopping, without overtaking (unless clearly necessary), without receiving any object whatsoever and without any assistance (except that of the marshals if necessary)."<ref>''[http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/548514743__2006_F1_SPORTING_REGULATIONS.pdf FIA Sporting Regulations] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060408104015/http://www.fia.com/resources/documents/548514743__2006_F1_SPORTING_REGULATIONS.pdf |date=April 8, 2006 }}'' FIA.com. Retrieved 23 October 2006</ref>
==Polish victory lap== [[Image:PolishVictoryLapIceRacing.jpg|thumb|right|A winning [[ice racing]] driver taking a Polish Victory Lap on a frozen [[Wisconsin]] lake]] A '''Polish''', or '''Kulwicki victory lap''' entails the driver turning his car around and driving in the opposite direction, which is clockwise on [[NASCAR]] ovals. It has been used in road courses.
This style of victory lap is common in local short track or dirt track races, where the victorious driver takes the [[Racing flag#The checkered flag|checkered flag]] from the flag stand, and then proceeds to drive with the driver's side of the car facing the fans for their victory lap.
The term was first [[neologism|coined]] as a result of [[Polish American]] [[Alan Kulwicki]]'s celebration of his first career [[Sprint Cup Series|Winston Cup]] victory at the [[Checker Auto Parts 500|Checker 500]] ([[Phoenix International Raceway|Phoenix]]) on November 6, 1988.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nascar.com/en_us/news-media/videos/2013/11/7/sprint-cup-series-memorable-moments-phoenix.html|title=Memorable Moments: Phoenix|work=[[NASCAR]]|date=November 7, 2013|accessdate=November 7, 2013}}</ref> He celebrated his victory by driving a clockwise victory lap. A [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] engineer slapped him on the back and asked if that was a "Polish" victory lap. Kulwicki's only other Polish Victory lap came in [[1992 in NASCAR|1992]], in celebration of his Winston Cup Championship at the [[1992 Hooters 500]].
The term was solidified after Kulwicki's death. Kulwicki died in a plane crash on Thursday, April 1, 1993, near [[Blountville, Tennessee]]. Hours after Kulwicki's death, Peter Jellen drove Kulwicki’s racecar hauler counter-clockwise around [[Bristol Motor Speedway]] before leaving the track.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.speedtv.com/articles/nascar/nextel/33878/?page=4 |pages=4 |title=CUP: A Tribute to Alan Kulwicki |accessdate=2007-07-09 |date=November 10, 2006 |publisher=[[Speed Channel]].com |author=Tom Jensen}}</ref> Two days after Kulwicki's death, [[Bristol Motor Speedway|Bristol]] [[Nationwide Series|Busch Series]] race winner [[Michael Waltrip]] honored his old short track foe by turning Kulwicki's trademark reverse Polish Victory Lap, but only half a lap, stating that he didn't want to do Kulwicki's entire routine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.underbird.com/news/toofast.htm|title=Sports|work=underbird.com|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref> The next day, Winston Cup winner [[Rusty Wallace]] followed Waltrip's lead,<ref>[https://sports.yahoo.com/nascar/news?slug=jb-rustybristol082605&prov=yhoo&type=lgns Rusty's last bash]; Jerry Bonkowski; [[Yahoo!]], August 25, 2005, Retrieved March 5, 2008</ref> and proceeded to run a full Polish Victory Lap, both after that race, and after each victory for the rest of the 1993 season. Tom Roberts, Wallace's and sponsor Miller Brewing's publicist, was also Kulwicki's publicist. In addition, most winners for the remainder of the [[1993 in NASCAR|1993 season]] honored Kulwicki with a Polish victory lap. On November 14, 1993, after the [[Labor Day Classic 500|Hooters 500]] ([[Atlanta Motor Speedway|Atlanta]]), the last race of that season, the race winner Wallace and 1993 series champion [[Dale Earnhardt]] ran a Polish Victory Lap together while carrying #7 and #28 flags commemorating Kulwicki and [[Davey Allison]], respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.underbird.com/news/inmemory.htm|title=SpeedwayMedia.com, In Memory of Alan--Ten Years Gone (Revisited)|work=underbird.com|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>
[[Mike Joy]] frequently refers to this as an "Alan Kulwicki victory lap" in memory of the driver, and noted the spectators see the driver, who usually waves and sometimes has his helmet off, as he salutes the fans. Joy's term is reminiscent of other cases where a term is named for the person who developed the idea (i. e., [[Gurney flap]], Petty bar). The term "Polish victory lap" is considered by some{{who|date=January 2016}} as [[political correctness|politically incorrect]], referring to [[Polish jokes]].
[[Dale Earnhardt, Jr.]] did a Polish victory lap after winning the [[2001 MBNA Cal Ripken, Jr. 400]] at [[Dover International Speedway|Dover Downs International Speedway]] in the first NASCAR Winston Cup Race following the [[September 11 attacks]] while holding a large American flag out the driver's side window.
[[Kurt Busch]] celebrated his 2005 win at Phoenix with a Polish victory lap. Busch watched his first NASCAR races at the track, and wanted to honor Kulwicki. [[Kyle Busch]] also did a Polish Victory Lap after his 2009 NASCAR Sprint Cup win at Bristol.
Many local racetrack winners and series champions have saluted Kulwicki or his underdog spirit with a Polish victory lap, especially in his home state of [[Wisconsin]]. 2006 [[Milwaukee Mile|Milwaukee]] (Wisconsin) race winner [[Paul Menard]] (a Wisconsinite) celebrated his first Busch Series win with a Polish Victory lap.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070312031735/http://www.motorsporttoday.com/2006-Busch-Milwaukee-Review.html Paul Menard captures first career Busch Series victory in Milwaukee]; Motorsport Today</ref>
Kurt Busch, with his win at Atlanta in Sprint Cup, 2009, ended up putting the car in reverse and driving it around the track backwards. His brother Kyle also used this after his win in Bristol. The practice was later dubbed, "The Unwind Lap".
In 2012, [[Tony Stewart]] did a Polish victory lap after finally winning for the first time at Las Vegas Motor Speedway in the Kobalt Tools 400.
In 2014, Earnhardt, Jr. celebrated his Daytona 500 victory with a Polish victory lap. His second win of the 2014 season came on June 8 at Pocono, where he repeated it. He also performed the feat after winning the [[2014 Goody's Headache Relief Shot 500|Goody's Headache Relief Shot 500]] in October.
In 2014, [[Denny Hamlin]] celebrated his [[Nationwide Series]] in his home state track at [[Richmond International Raceway]] with a Polish Victory Lap, and completing it while performing a burnout.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2kVA4JhoF-k|title=Hamlin delivers a win in home state|date=24 April 2015|work=YouTube|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox women |image = ZiynetSali.jpg |caption = [[Ziynet Sali]], a female singer from Northern Cyprus |gii = |gii_rank = |matdeath = |womparl = 18% (2018) |femed = |womlab = 39-40% (2015) | ggg = | ggg_rank = | ggg_ref = }} {{Women in society sidebar}} The '''women in Northern Cyprus''' are inhabitants of the internationally unrecognised [[Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus]], where they have been contributors to the fields of science, law and justice.<ref name=Cypnet>{{cite web|url=http://www.cypnet.co.uk/ncyprus/people/women/sayiner-g.html|title=Turkish-Cypriot Women: Dr Gülin Sayiner|author=|date=|website=www.cypnet.co.uk|accessdate=7 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231152/http://www.cypnet.co.uk/ncyprus/people/women/sayiner-g.html|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}}</ref> However, several factors have inhibited women's participation in politics, and women constitute only 8% of the [[Assembly of the Republic (Northern Cyprus)|Assembly of the Republic]]. In 2013, [[Sibel Siber]] became the first female prime minister of Northern Cyprus.
Northern Cyprus has no active women's shelters. In 2014, the parliament unanimously voted to establish a department promoting gender equality, which is establishing institutions for women's welfare.
== Societal attitudes == A survey of 600 women in 2010 for the Association for Support for Life from Women (KAYAD) indicated that 51% of women agreed that women had to conform to pre-determined gender roles, 88% agreed that above all else, women should be good mothers and caretakers of the home, 58% believed that women should be home before their husbands and 80% believed that girls should be raised to become "ladies", 20% believed that widowed or divorced women should not live alone. 40% stated that they had difficulties in achieving their goals due to societal pressure, while 38% believed that it was not as important for women to have a significant role in public life in comparison to men. 55% believed that women should be able to work outside the family even if not necessitated by economic conditions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kıbrıs’ın Kuzey Kesimindeki Kadınların Profili|url=http://kayadcommunitycenter.com/KadinProfili.pdf|publisher=KAYAD|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914030159/http://kayadcommunitycenter.com/KadinProfili.pdf|archivedate=14 September 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Politics == Constraints affecting women who have entered politics in Northern Cyprus include investing time for home, motherhood, family, and political life. The fact that [[coffeehouse]]s and [[meyhane]] (traditional drinking taverns), social spaces that have been traditionally reserved for men, remain central to Turkish Cypriot politics is a restraining factor for women. Even some regional headquarters of political parties function as coffeehouses.<ref name=Index>Yirmibeolu, Gözde. [http://www.indexcyprus.com/site/index.php?option=com_myblog&show=Constraints-on-Women-Politicians-in-Northern-Cyprus-Research-Essay.html&Itemid=202 Constraints on Women Politicians in Northern Cyprus - Research Essay], January 10, 2010</ref><ref name=Deep>Yirmibeolu, Gözde. [http://www.deepdyve.com/lp/emerald-publishing/constraints-on-women-politicians-in-northern-cyprus-Uf3GE190td Constraints on Women Politicians in Northern Cyprus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721153954/http://www.deepdyve.com/lp/emerald-publishing/constraints-on-women-politicians-in-northern-cyprus-Uf3GE190td |date=2011-07-21 }}</ref><ref name=ozdenefe>{{cite web|title=Özdenefe: "Örneğimiz Siber"|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/121106|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215173801/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/121106|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Dürüst|first1=Çiğdem|title=Kadınları bıyık da paklamayacak (sakal şart)|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/1/col/146/art/14287/PageName/KIBRIS_POSTASI|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215173804/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/1/col/146/art/14287/PageName/KIBRIS_POSTASI|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
===Female politicians=== As of 2010, there were only 7 female Northern Cypriots who held high-level positions in the [[Parliament of Northern Cyprus]].<ref name=Index/> The posts that the women occupied included parliamentarian and ministerial jobs, such as the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the appointed Minister of Education. [[Fatma Ekenoğlu]] was the Speaker of the House of Representatives. [[Onur Borman]] was the Minister of the Ministry of Economy and Finance and was also the Minister of the Ministry of Public Works between 1993 and 1999. [[Gülsen Bozkurt]] was the former Minister of the Ministry of Health. [[Gülin Sayıner]] was one of the first two elected female members of the Parliament of Northern Cyprus (Republican Assembly) and served from 1987 to 1993.<ref name=Cypnet/> [[Şerife Ünverdi]] used to be the Minister of Labor and Social Security.<ref>[http://www.brtk.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=26807:messages-have-been-issued-by-president-dervis-eroglu-prime-minister-irsen-kucuk-and-minister-of-labor-and-social-security-serife-unverdi&catid=5:kktc&Itemid=28 MESSAGES HAVE BEEN ISSUED BY PRESIDENT DERVIS EROGLU, PRIME MINISTER IRSEN KUCUK AND MINISTER OF LABOR AND SOCIAL SECURITY SERIFE UNVERDI] ([[Bayrak|BRT]]) Retrieved 2010-05-06.</ref> These women were able to reach out to voters of Northern Cyprus because of their medical backgrounds.<ref name=Index/><ref name=Deep/> In 2013, [[Sibel Siber]] became the first female prime minister of Northern Cyprus<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx?pageID=238&nid=48659 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141019095831/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/Default.aspx?pageID=238&nid=48659 |archivedate=2014-10-19 |df= }} Turkish Cyprus to see first female prime minister, Hürriyet Daily News, 12 June 2013</ref> and is running for president from the ruling [[Republican Turkish Party]] (CTP) in the [[Northern Cyprus presidential election, 2015|2015]] presidential election.<ref>{{cite web|title=CTP'NİN CUMHURBAŞKANI ADAYI SİBER|url=http://www.yeniduzen.com/Haberler/siyaset/ctpnin-cumhurbaskani-adayi-siber/42349|publisher=[[Yeni Düzen]]|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215171849/http://www.yeniduzen.com/Haberler/siyaset/ctpnin-cumhurbaskani-adayi-siber/42349|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref> In spite of this, women constitute only 8% of the parliament as of 2015. Only 4 out of 47 female candidates were elected in the [[Northern Cyprus parliamentary election, 2013|2013 parliamentary election]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kadın milletvekilleri yine azınlıkta!|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/111243|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215185816/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/111243|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
On February 29, 1980, [[Gönül Başaran Erönen]] became the first female Justice of Northern Cyprus. She was also appointed as the first female District Court Judge in Cyprus. At present, she is the only female justice of the Supreme Court on the whole island of Cyprus.<ref name=Eronen>[http://www.cypnet.co.uk/ncyprus/people/women/eronen.html Gönül Başaran Erönen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014204443/http://cypnet.co.uk/ncyprus/people/women/eronen.html |date=2010-10-14 }}, First woman Justice of the T.R. of Northern Cyprus], Turkish-Cypriot Women, People & Life, cypnet.co.uk</ref>
In 2015, a new Political Parties Law brought a quota requiring that at least 30% of candidates for member of parliament are selected from each sex by each party. Any party that does not fulfill this requirement may not participate in elections.<ref>{{cite web|title=Barajı geçememesine karşın en az yüzde 3 oy alan partiler devlet yardımı alabilecek|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/174662/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=26 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151027143256/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/174662/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI|archivedate=27 October 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Violence against women == In 2014, 204 women filed complaints to the police reporting violence against them. [[Aziz Gürpınar]], the Minister of Labour and Social Security at the time, called the figure "frightening".<ref>{{cite web|title=Kadınlar şiddet kurbanı|url=http://www.kibrisgazetesi.com/?p=728246|publisher=Kıbrıs|accessdate=10 July 2016|date=23 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820175706/http://www.kibrisgazetesi.com/?p=728246|archivedate=20 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Between 2013 and 2015, the number of complaints was 442 in total, and according to [[Asım Akansoy]], Minister of the Interior at the time, only 10% of victims were estimated to have reported violence. Northern Cyprus ratified the [[Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence|Istanbul Convention]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=İçişleri Bakanı'ndan 'Kadına Şiddet' Raporu|url=http://haberkibris.com/icisleri-bakanindan-kadina--siddet-raporu-2016-02-16.html|publisher=Haber Kıbrıs|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820015431/http://haberkibris.com/icisleri-bakanindan-kadina--siddet-raporu-2016-02-16.html|archivedate=20 August 2016|df=}}</ref> A survey of 1000 married women in 2012 by the non-governmental organization Feminist Workshop found that 33% of married women experienced violence, while the participants reported knowing on average 2.58 women who experienced violence from their partners. 14% of women reported having experienced [[marital rape]].<ref name="femasurvey">{{cite web|title=Kıbrıs’ın Kuzeyinde Aile İçi Şiddet|url=http://www.yeniduzen.com/Ekler/gaile/241/kibris-in-kuzeyinde-aile-ici-siddet/916|publisher=Yeni Düzen|accessdate=10 July 2016|date=1 December 2013}}</ref>
Due to the lack of a reliable public transport system, students in Northern Cyprus sometimes have to hitchhike. Students have reported that female students often face sexual harassment in these hikes, while male students also reported harassment.<ref>{{cite web|title=KKTC’de kadın ve erkek öğrenciler tacize uğruyor!|url=http://www.kibrisadahaber.com/kktcde-kadin-ve-erkek-ogrenciler-tacize-ugruyor.html|publisher=Kıbrıs Ada Haber|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160815230859/http://www.kibrisadahaber.com/kktcde-kadin-ve-erkek-ogrenciler-tacize-ugruyor.html|archivedate=15 August 2016|df=}}</ref>
== Employment == According to a 2015 survey by the State Planning Organization, 39-40% of women participated in the workforce as opposed to 71-72% of men. Female unemployment rate was found to be 8.9%, as opposed to 6.5% for men, and 36.5% of all employees were women. It was also found that 85.7% of women were employed in the services sector, as opposed to 67.8% of men.<ref>{{cite web|title=Devlet Planlama Örgütü 2015 Hanehalkı İşgücü Anketi Sonuçları|url=http://www.devplan.org/Isgucu/2015.pdf|publisher=State Planning Organization|accessdate=10 July 2016|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817074155/http://www.devplan.org/Isgucu/2015.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=}}</ref> The same survey in 2008 indicated that only 36.2% of women participated in the workforce as opposed to 67.1% of men. Female unemployment rate was found to be 14%, as opposed to 7.6% for men, and 32.6% of all employees were women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Devlet Planlama Örgütü 2008 Hanehalkı İşgücü Anketi Sonuçları karnesi|url=http://www.devplan.org/Isgucu/2008.pdf|publisher=State Planning Organization|accessdate=10 July 2016|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817124813/http://www.devplan.org/Isgucu/2008.pdf|archivedate=17 August 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=İşgücüne katılım oranları karnesi|url=http://feministatolye.org/index.php/kibrisfem/tcekarnesi/53-isgucunekatilim|publisher=Feminist Workshop|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215183330/http://feministatolye.org/index.php/kibrisfem/tcekarnesi/53-isgucunekatilim|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
The Plan for the Support of Local Employment, whose implementation started in 2013, prioritised the increase of women's participation in the workforce. The plan resulted in the employment of 2091 women along with 1812 men until January 2015. The plan also allowed 78 women to start businesses in 39 sectors. These women owned their own businesses for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kadınların işgücüne katılımı konusunda atılan adımlar meyve vermeye başladı|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/154060/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150728001630/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/154060/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI|archivedate=28 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Organizations== The first and only<ref name=FSD>[http://www.fsd.org.qa/common/ngo/ngo/1998.html Center for Women's Studies(CWS)], fsd.org.qa</ref> academic research and training center for women in Northern Cyprus is the Center for Women's Studies (CWS) of the [[Eastern Mediterranean University]] (EMU). It was established on November 17, 1998.<ref name=Emu>[http://www.emu.edu.tr/academic/researchcenters/cws.aspx CENTER FOR WOMEN’S STUDIES (CWS)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430022717/http://www.emu.edu.tr/academic/researchcenters/cws.aspx |date=2011-04-30 }}, Eastern Mediterranean University, emu.edu.tr</ref> The Cyprus Research Center of the [[Near East University]] also conducts research on women's human rights in Northern Cyprus.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kıbrıs Araştırmaları Merkezi (YDÜ-KAM)|url=http://neu.edu.tr/en/node/6131|publisher=Near East University|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215183003/http://neu.edu.tr/en/node/6131|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref> The first women's shelter in Northern Cyprus was opened by the Foundation for the Prevention of Social Risks in 2011; the center has been supported by volunteers and companies. However, the shelter was unable to host the victims of human trafficking and prostitution due to concerns over safety and lack of resources.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sığınma Evi "gönülle" yürüyor|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/85/news/125849/PageName/toplum|publisher=Kıbrıs Postası|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215173811/http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/85/news/125849/PageName/toplum|archivedate=15 February 2015|df=}}</ref> In 2016, the shelter was permanently closed due to difficulties with security.<ref>{{cite web|title=“Artık KKTC'de kadınların sığınabileceği bir yer yok”|url=http://www.kibrisgazetesi.com/?p=812008|publisher=Kıbrıs|accessdate=10 July 2016|date=10 July 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160710145420/http://www.kibrisgazetesi.com/?p=812008|archivedate=10 July 2016|df=}}</ref>
In 2014, the Turkish Cypriot parliament unanimously approved the establishment of the Communal Gender Equality Department under the Ministry of Labor and Social Security. The department has prioritized the establishment of women's shelters, Violence Prevention and Consultation Centers, a Council of Consultation and Monitoring and organizing annual gender equality conferences.<ref>{{cite web|title=TOCED gün sayıyor!|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/123730/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI|publisher=[[Kıbrıs Postası]]|accessdate=15 February 2015|language=Turkish}}</ref>

{{Infobox women by region | image = [[File:MunaWassefCropped.jpg|frameless|center]][[File:Asma_al-Assad.jpg|frameless|center]] | caption = | gii = 0.556 (2013) | gii_rank = 125th out of 152 | gii_ref = <ref name=gii>{{cite web|title=Table 4: Gender Inequality Index|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/table-4-gender-inequality-index|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> | matdeath = 70 (2010) | womparl = 13% (2015)<ref>http://www.ipu.org/WMN-e/classif.htm</ref> | femed = 29.0% (2012) | womlab = 15% (2014)<ref>http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.ACTI.FE.ZS</ref> | ggg = 0.5661 (2013) | ggg_rank = 133rd | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} '''Women in Syria''' constitute 49.4% of Syria's population,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://countrymeters.info/en/Syria|title = Syria Population|last = |first = |date = 7 Apr 2015|journal = Syria Population|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> and are active participants not only in everyday life, but also in the socio-political fields. The [[Syrian Civil War]] put a new obstacle on Syrian women, forcing them to face increasing levels of violence, including [[war rape]], and traditional abusive practices such as [[honor killings]] which occur in rural areas and areas held by extremist terrorists.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
== History == In the 20th century a movement for [[women's rights]] developed in Syria, made up largely of upper-class, educated women.<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=edited by Bonnie G.|title=Women's history in global perspective|year=2005|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana, Ill.|isbn=9780252029905|page=100}}</ref> In 1919, [[Naziq al-Abid]] founded Noor al-Fayha (Light of Damascus), the city's first women's organization, alongside an affiliated publication of the same name. She was made an honorary general of the [[Syrian Army]] after fighting in the [[Battle of Maysaloun]], and in 1922 she founded the [[Syrian Red Crescent]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Syrian Women Making Change|url=https://www.pbs.org/pov/thelightinhereyes/syrian-women-making-change-past-and-present.php|accessdate=15 March 2013|publisher=PBS|date=19 July 2012}}</ref> In 1928 Lebanese-Syrian feminist [[Nazira Zain al-Din]], one of the first people to critically reinterpret the [[Quran]] from a feminist perspective, published a book condemning the practice of veiling or [[hijab]], arguing that [[Islam]] requires women to be treated equally with men.<ref>{{cite book|last=Keddie|first=Nikki R.|title=Women in the Middle East: past and present|year=2007|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton|isbn=9780691128634|page=96}}</ref>
In 1963 the [[Ba'th Party]] took power in Syria, and pledged full equality between women and men as well as full workforce participation for women.<ref name="Tohidi 1998 103">{{cite book|last=Tohidi|first=ed. by Herbert L. Bodman, Nayereh|title=Women in muslim societies: diversity within unity|year=1998|publisher=L. Rienner|location=Boulder (Colo.)|isbn=9781555875787|page=103}}</ref>
In 1967 Syrian women formed a quasi-governmental organization called the [[General Union of Syrian Women]] (GUSW), a coalition of women's welfare societies, educational associations, and voluntary councils intended to achieve equal opportunity for women in Syria.<ref name="Tohidi 1998 103"/>
The year 2011 marked the beginning of the conflict throughout Syria where many innocent civilians fell victims to the war perpetuated by the freedom fighters, who targeted hospitals, schools and the country’s infrastructure. And in rebel held areas, women were particularly targeted due to them being perceived as weak and lesser than men.
The Syrian women in conflict areas were terrorized and forced into hiding to avoid being caught and raped by the men fighting for ISIS/ISIL or the freedom fighters. Women and children were also forced to appear in videos serving the propaganda against the Syrian government and the army, in many cases under the threat of violence. In cases where women were pro-ISIS, pro-Rebels, they were active in the terrorist acts committed against innocent Syrian civilians by blowing themselves up near primary schools, causing the death of young children, and hospitals in order to destroy public access to healthcare.
Some were active participants in “Jihad al-Nikah” <ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_jihad</ref>where they served as nothing more than bodies used for sex, traded between the so-called freedom fighters, with many falling pregnant and bearing children into the war serving as nothing more than tools in the propaganda against Bashar Al-Assad’s government. And despite the numerous claims of the MSM; throughout the entire country, many Syrian women are pro-government and pro-Bashar Al-Assad and vehement supporters of the Syrian Arab Army.
In response to the violence conducted by the terrorists against them, many ordinary Syrian women joined the all-female brigade unit that is part of the constitutional army of the Syrian Arab Republic and joined the fight against the ISIL/ISIS terrorists; where some took the roles of snipers to avoid direct-combat areas and others actively fought on the frontlines, side by side with their male counterparts in the army. <ref>https://arabic.sputniknews.com/arab_world/201610171020473107-نساء-تقاتل-بجانب-الجيش-السوري/</ref>
They are applauded for their bravery and dedication to the homeland by the Syrian populace, echoing the bravery of the women in Syria throughout its long, ancient history.
== Legal rights == While Syria has developed some fairly secular features during independence in the second half of the 20th century, [[personal status]] law is still based on [[Sharia]]<ref name=Sharia1>{{cite web|title=Syria|url=http://www.carnegieendowment.org/files/Syria_APS.doc|publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|page=13|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> and applied by Sharia Courts.<ref name=Sharia2>{{cite web|url=https://scholarblogs.emory.edu/islamic-family-law/home/research/legal-profiles/syria-syrian-arab-republic/|title=Islamic Family Law: Syria (Syrian Arab Republic)|publisher=Law.emory.edu|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> Syria has a dual legal system which includes both secular and religious courts, and the latter discriminate against women.<ref>https://www.unicef.org/gender/files/Syria-Gender-Eqaulity-Profile-2011.pdf</ref> [[Marriage contracts]] are between the groom and the bride's father, and Syrian law does not recognize the concept of [[marital rape]].<ref name="Syria Capabilities Approach">{{cite journal|last=Charles|first=Lorraine|author2=Kate Denman |title="Every knot has someone to undo it." Using the Capabilities Approach as a lens to view the status of women leading up to the Arab Spring in Syria|journal=Journal of International Women's Studies|date=October 2012|volume=13|issue=5|pages=195–211}}</ref>
Syrian women are legally allowed to participate in everyday life, although they are not guaranteed a spot in being part of political, social, cultural and economic categories. The legal marriage for females in Syria is seventeen years old and eighteen for males. Early marriage is not out of the ordinary in their culture. Even though the legal age is seventeen, the courts can allow for girls as young as thirteen to be married. Women are technically allowed to have a say in what the agreements are between them and the groom. Although, since this contract has to be signed by the groom and the male guardian of the bride, her wishes are rarely met. On the other hand, of marriage, the divorce laws are unique in Syria. Women are in fact allowed to file for divorce except it is a long drawn out process and she must get consent from her husband. There are some circumstances in which the woman can apply for a divorce through the judicial system. In order to do this, she must prove that her husband has abused her or neglected his other duties as a husband. If a man wants to divorce a woman, all he has to do is go to court and orally demand a divorce three times, then the court will order him a divorce.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Legal rights - Syria {{!}} Kvinfo.dk|url = http://kvinfo.org/mena/legal-rights-syria-0|website = kvinfo.org|accessdate = 2015-04-21}}</ref>
== Education ==
The early schooling in Syria starts at six years old and ends at the age of eighteen. In Syrian universities, women and men attend the same classes. Between 1970 and the late 1990s, the female population in schools dramatically increased. This increase included the early school years, along with the upper level schools such as universities. Although the number of women has increased, there are still ninety five women to every one hundred men. Although many women start going to school, the dropout rate for women is much higher than for men.
The literacy rate for women is 74.2 percent and 91 percent for men. The rate of females over 25 with secondary education is 29.0 percent.<ref name=gii/>
== Politics ==
In 1949, women in Syria were first allowed to vote and received universal suffrage in 1953.<ref>{{cite book|last=Pamela|first=Paxton|title=Women, Politics, and Power: A Global Perspective|year=2007|publisher=Pine Forge Press|location=Thousand Oaks, California|pages=48–49}}</ref> In the 1950s, [[Thuraya Al-Hafez]] ran for [[People's Council of Syria|Parliament]], but was not elected. By 1971, women held four out of the 173 seats.<ref>{{cite web|last=Moubayed|first=Sami|title=A History of Syrian Women|url=http://onfaith.washingtonpost.com/postglobal/needtoknow/2006/12/a_history_of_syrian_women.html|publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref>
The current president of Syria is a male. There are also two vice presidents (including female vice president [[Najah al-Attar]] since 2006), a prime minister and a cabinet. As of 2012, in the national parliament men held 88% of the seats while women held 12%.<ref name="Syrian Arab Republic"/> The [[People's Council of Syria|Syrian Parliament]] was previously led by female [[Speaker of the People's Council of Syria|Speaker]] [[Hadiya Khalaf Abbas]], the first woman to have held that position.<ref name=SANA>{{cite news |title=250 New Parliament Members Take Constitutional Oath |author= |url=http://syriatimes.sy/index.php/news/local/24397-250-new-parliament-members-take-constitutional-oath |publisher=[[Syria Times]] |date=6 June 2016 |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
President Assad's political and media adviser is [[Bouthaina Shaaban]]. Shaaban served as the first [[Ministry of Expatriates (Syria)|Minister of Expatriates]] for the [[Syrian Arab Republic]], between 2003 and 2008,<ref>{{cite book |title=Dreams and Shadows: the Future of the Middle East |last=Wright |first=Robin B.|authorlink=Robin Wright (author) |year=2008 |publisher=Penguin Group |location= |isbn=978-1-59420-111-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nzXA7PZdO0AC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Dreams+and+Shadows+:+the+Future+of+the+Middle+East&ei=trTBS5CyMqaukAS39ITOCQ&cd=1#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and she has been described as the Syrian government's face to the outside world.{{fact|date=May 2018}}
== Role in economy and in the military ==
In 1989 the Syrian government passed a law requiring factories and public institutions to provide on-site childcare.<ref name="Tohidi 1998 103"/>
However, women's involvement in the workforce is low; according to [[World Bank]], as of 2014, women made up 15.5% of the labor force.<ref>http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.TOTL.FE.ZS</ref>
Women are not conscripted in the military, but may serve voluntarily. The female militias of Syria are trained to fight for the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad. A video was found dating back to the 1980s with female soldiers showing their pride and protectiveness toward Assad's father.<ref>{{Cite news|title = The all-female militias of Syria|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/01/25/the-all-female-militias-of-syria/|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2013-01-25|access-date = 2015-04-21|issn = 0190-8286|first = Liz|last = Sly|first2 = Ahmed|last2 = Ramadan}}</ref> "Because women are rarely involved in the armed side of the revolution, they are much less likely to get stopped, searched, or hassled at government checkpoints. This has proved crucial in distributing humanitarian aid throughout Syria."<ref name="foreignaffairs.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/syria/2013-03-06/how-syrian-women-are-fueling-resistance|title=How Syrian Women Are Fueling the Resistance|date=2013-03-07|website=Foreign Affairs|access-date=2016-09-06}}</ref>
== Women's health ==
Between 2010 and 2015, the average life expectancy at birth for women in Syria is 77.7 years, compared with 74.5 years for men.<ref name="Syrian Arab Republic">{{cite web|title=Syrian Arab Republic|url=http://data.un.org/CountryProfile.aspx?crName=Syrian+Arab+Republic|publisher=United Nations Statistics Division|accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>
== Crime against women == ===Honor killings=== [[Honor killings]] take place in Syria in situations where women are deemed to have brought shame to the family, affecting the family's 'reputation' in the community. Some estimates suggest that more than 200 honor killings occur every year in [[Syria]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7042249.stm | work=BBC News | first=Lina | last=Sinjab | title=Honour crime fear of Syria women | date=12 October 2007}}</ref>
===Forced and child marriage=== The conflict in Syria has led to an increase in child marriages.. The harsh living conditions, the insecurity, and the fear of rape, have led families to force their daughters into early marriages.<ref>https://europa.eu/eyd2015/en/unfpa/stories/child-marriage-takes-toll-syrian-girls</ref> <ref>http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-14/child-brides-number-in-sryria-triples-since-conflict/6851248?pfmredir=sm</ref>
=== '''Domestic Violence''' === Physical abuse (battering at least 3 times in the last year) was found in 23% of the investigated women in 2003, 26% amongst married women. Regular abuse (battering at least once weekly) was found in 3.3% of married women, with no regular abused reported by non-married women. The prevalence of physical abuse amongst country residents was 44.3% compared to 18.8% amongst country residents. In most cases (87.4%) the abuse was inflected by the husband, and in 9.5% of cases, the abuse was inflicted by more than one person. Correlates of physical abuse was women's education, religion, age, marital status, economic status, mental distress, smoking and residence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maziak|first=Wasim|last2=Asfar|first2=Taghrid|date=2003-04|title=PHYSICAL ABUSE IN LOW-INCOME WOMEN IN ALEPPO, SYRIA|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/07399330390191689|journal=Health Care for Women International|language=en|volume=24|issue=4|pages=313–326|doi=10.1080/07399330390191689|issn=0739-9332}}</ref>
== Federation of Northern Syria - Rojava == {{Further information|Rojava|Jineology|Kongreya Star}}
[[File:Kurdish female fighter.jpg|thumb|200 px|right|Member of the YPJ with a standard uniform]]
With the [[Syrian Civil War]], the Kurdish populated area in Northern Syria has gained de facto autonomy as the [[Rojava|Federation of Northern Syria - Rojava]], with the leading political actor being the progressive [[Democratic Union Party (Syria)|Democratic Union Party]] (PYD). Kurdish women have several armed and non-armed organizations in Rojava, and enhancing women's rights is a major focus of the political and societal agenda. Kurdish female fighters in the [[Women's Protection Units]] (YPJ) played a key role during the [[Siege of Kobani]] and in rescuing [[Yazidis]] trapped on [[Mount Sinjar]], and their achievements have attracted international attention as a rare example of strong female achievement in a region in which women are heavily repressed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudaw.net/english/middleeast/05032015|title=Female Kurdish fighters battling ISIS win Israeli hearts|work=Rudaw|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ctQFgDabh1U|title=The Fight Against ISIS in Syria And Iraq December 2014 by Itai Anghel|date=22 December 2014|work=The Israeli Network via YouTube|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tin.tv/site/show/cat2/fact-2012-uvda|title=Fact 2015 (Uvda) – Israel’s leading investigative show|date=22 December 2014|work=The Israeli Network|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rudaw.net/english/world/26122014|title=Kurdish female fighters named ‘most inspiring women’ of 2014|work=Rudaw|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/kobani-how-sacrifice-local-knowledge-heroism-kurdish-female-fighters-beat-isis-1487358|title=Kobani: How strategy, sacrifice and heroism of Kurdish female fighters beat Isis|work=International Business Times UK|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
The civil laws of Syria are valid in Rojava, as far as they do not conflict with the Constitution of Rojava. One notable example for amendment is personal status law, in Syria still Sharia-based,<ref name=Sharia1/><ref name=Sharia2/> where Rojava introduced civil law and proclaims absolute equality of women under the law and a ban on [[forced marriage]] as well as [[polygamy]] was introduced,<ref name=jolie>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-37337908|title=Kurdish 'Angelina Jolie' devalued by media hype|work=BBC|date=2016-09-12|accessdate=2016-09-12}}</ref> while underage marriage was outlawed as well.<ref name=underage>{{cite web|url=http://aranews.net/2016/11/syrian-kurds-tackle-underage-marriages-polygamy/|title=Syrian Kurds tackle conscription, underage marriages and polygamy|work=ARA News|date=15 November 2016|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> For the first time in Syrian history, [[civil marriage]] is being allowed and promoted, a significant move towards a secular open society and intermarriage between people of different religious backgrounds.<ref name=marriage>{{cite web|title=Syria Kurds challenging traditions, promote civil marriage|url=http://aranews.net/2016/02/syria-kurds-challenging-traditions-promote-civil-marriage/|publisher=ARA News|date=2016-02-20|accessdate=2016-08-23}}</ref>
The legal efforts to reduce cases of underage marriage, polygamy and [[honor killings]] are underpinned by comprehensive public awareness campaigns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Syrian Kurds give women equal rights, snubbing jihadists|url=https://news.yahoo.com/syrian-kurds-women-equal-rights-snubbing-jihadists-193905057.html|website=Yahoo News|accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref> In every town and village, a women's house is established. These are community centers run by women, providing services to survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault and other forms of harm. These services include counseling, family mediation, legal support, and coordinating safe houses for women and children.<ref name="gender">{{cite web |last1=Owen |first1=Margaret |title=Gender and justice in an emerging nation: My impressions of Rojava, Syrian Kurdistan |url=https://ceasefiremagazine.co.uk/gender-justice-emerging-nation-impressions-rojava-syrian-kurdistan/|accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref> Classes on economic independence and social empowerment programs are also held at women's houses.<ref>{{cite web |title=Revolution in Rojava transformed the perception of women in the society |url=http://www.sosyalistfeministkolektif.org/english/928-revolution-in-rojava-transformed-the-perception-of-women-in-the-society.html|accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref>
All administrative organs in Rojava are required to have male and female co-chairs, and forty percent of the members of any governing body in Rojava must be female.<ref name=rojavamodel>{{cite web|title=The Rojava Model|publisher=Foreign Affairs|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/2016-10-14/rojava-model|date=14 October 2016}}</ref> An estimated 25 percent of the [[Asayish (Syria)|Asayish]] police force of the Rojava cantons are women, and joining the Asayish is described in international media as a huge act of personal and societal liberation from an extremely patriarchical background, for ethnic Kurdish and ethnic Arab women alike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Syrian women liberated from Isis are joining the police to protect their city|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/isis-syria-women-liberated-create-police-force-a7359376.html|publisher=The Independent|date=13 October 2016|accessdate=2016-10-14}}</ref>
The PYD's political agenda of "trying to break the honor-based religious and tribal rules that confine women" is controversial in conservative quarters of society.<ref name=underage />
== Notable women == * [[Hadiya Khalaf Abbas]], Speaker of the [[People's Council of Syria]] (since 2016). * [[Asya Abdullah]] is the co-chairwoman of the [[Democratic Union Party (Syria)|Democratic Union Party]] (PYD), the leading political party in [[Rojava]]. * [[Asma al-Assad]], the [[First Lady]] of Syria and the wife of the current President Assad * [[Najah al-Attar]], Vice President of Syria (since 2006). * [[Farah al-Atassi]] is a prominent Syrian American Business Woman, intellectual and public influencer. * [[Suheir Atassi]], Vice President of the [[National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces|opposition government]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20295857 Syria crisis: Gulf states recognise Syria opposition]</ref> * [[Khawla Dunia]], opposition activist and poet * [[Îlham Ehmed]] is co-chairwoman of the [[Syrian Democratic Council]]. * [[Hêvî Îbrahîm]] is the prime minister of [[Afrin Canton]]. * [[Samira Khalil]], dissident * [[Ulfat Idilbi]], best-selling Arabic-language novelist. * [[Assala Nasri]] is a musical artist * [[Rasha Omran]], poet * [[Bouthaina Shaaban]], Bashar al-Assad's political adviser and previous [[Ministry of Expatriates (Syria)|Minister of Expatriates]] * [[Muna Wassef]], theater, television, and film actress. * [[Hediya Yousef]] is an ex-guerilla and co-chairwoman of the executive committee of the [[Rojava|Federation of Northern Syria – Rojava]]. * [[Razan Zaitouneh]], human rights lawyer and activist.

{{Infobox Organization | name = World Association for Public Opinion Research | image = WAPOR logo.png | abbreviation = WAPOR | motto = | formation = {{start date and age|1947}} | extinction = | type = [[Professional association]] | headquarters =Lincoln, Nebraska, USA | location = | membership = > 400 | leader_title = [[President#Non-governmental presidents|President]] | leader_name = Claire Durand (2017-2018) | num_staff = | budget = | website = http://wapor.org }}
The '''World Association for Public Opinion Research''' ('''WAPOR''') is an [[international nongovernmental organization|international]] [[professional association]] of [[researcher]]s in the fields of [[communication studies|communication]] and [[survey research]]. It is a member organization of the [[International Social Science Council]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.unl.edu/wapor/social_science.html | title = International Social Science Council | accessdate = 2007-11-03 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research}}</ref>
== History == Established in 1947 at the Second International Conference on Public Opinion Research held in [[Williamstown, Massachusetts]]<ref name="dodd"> {{cite journal | last = Dodd | first = Stuart C. |date=Spring 1957 | title = The World Association for Public Opinion Research | journal = [[Public Opinion Quarterly]] | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 179–84 | doi = 10.1086/266698 | jstor=2746801}}</ref><ref> {{cite journal |author1=Hart, Clyde W. |author2=Don Cahalan |lastauthoramp=yes |date=Spring 1957 | title = The Development of AAPOR | journal = [[Public Opinion Quarterly]] | volume = 21 | issue = 1 | pages = 165–73 | doi = 10.1086/266696 | jstor=2746799}}</ref> as the World Congress on Public Opinion Research, the association acquired its current name in 1948, at the Third International Conference on Public Opinion Research.<ref> {{cite book | author = [[Stein Rokkan|Rokkan, Stein]] (ed) | title = A Quarter Century of International Social Science: Papers and Reports on Developments, 1952-1977 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=VwIwAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22&q=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | year = 1979 | publisher = Concept | location = | oclc = 7575815 | page = 279}}</ref> In 1953, it became the sole nongovernment consultant organization to [[UNESCO]] in the field of polling.<ref name="dodd"/>
Its current [[President#Non-governmental presidents|president]] is [[Claire Durand]] ([[University of Montreal]]) and the vice president is [[Marita Carballo]] ([[Voices Research and Consultancy]], in [[Argentina]]).<ref> {{cite web | url = http://wapor.unl.edu/executive-council/ | title = Executive Council | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research}}</ref> Among the former presidents of WAPOR are [[Juan Linz]], [[Elisabeth Noelle-Neumann]], [[Robert Worcester]] and [[Seymour Martin Lipset]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://wapor.unl.edu/history/ | title = History | accessdate = 2007-11-03 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research}}</ref>
=== Membership === Over time, WAPOR's membership has grown and become more international. In 1956, roughly a decade after its founding, the association had 158 members from about 20 countries;<ref name="dodd"/> by 1962, these figures had risen to approximately 200 and more than 30, respectively.<ref> {{Cite book | title = Encyclopedia Americana | url = https://books.google.com/?id=C_lLAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22&q=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | year = 1965 | volume = 22 | publisher = Americana Corporation | pages = 774}}</ref> In 1970, WAPOR had more than 300 members from 41 countries.<ref> {{Cite book | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | url = https://books.google.com/?id=OMgqAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22&q=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | year = 1974 | volume = 15 | publisher = [[Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.]] | isbn = 0-85229-290-2 | pages = 214 | author = Warren E. Preece, editor.}}</ref>
As of 2016, the association has over 400 members from [[research institute]]s and universities in over 60 countries on six continents.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://wapor.unl.edu/membership/ | title = Membership Information | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research}}</ref>
== Activities == WAPOR sponsors the ''[[International Journal of Public Opinion Research]]'', a [[List of social science journals|social science journal]] published by [[Oxford University Press]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://ijpor.oxfordjournals.org/ | title = Oxford Journals: Social Sciences – Int. Journal of Public Opinion Research | accessdate = 2007-02-21 | year = 2007 | publisher = [[Oxford Journals]] }}</ref>
Annual [[academic conference|conference]] are held in a three-year cycle: with [[American Association for Public Opinion Research]] (AAPOR) in North America (2016), in connection with either [[European Society for Opinion and Marketing Research]] (ESOMAR) or ESRA in Europe (2017), and in the third year in a new location (2018). This arrangement permits WAPOR members to meet with academic, commercial, and government researchers from the main centers of survey research around the globe. Our most recent annual conference was held Austin, Texas, USA during the dates of May 10-12, 2016. <ref> {{cite web | url = http://wapor.org/seminars-events/ | title = Conferences and Seminars | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research }}</ref> AAPOR and ESOMAR are considered "allied associations."<ref>[http://wapor.unl.edu/ WAPOR homepage ''(accessed 26 December 2012)'']</ref>
Since 1981, WAPOR offers the Helen Dinerman Award – created to honour sociologist [[Helen Dinerman]] – to individuals who have made "significant contributions to survey research methodology".<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.unl.edu/WAPOR/awards.html | title = Awards and Prizes | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research }}</ref> Prior recipients include social scientists [[Philip Converse]], [[Louis Guttman]],<ref> {{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = World of Sociology | title = Louis Guttman | url = http://www.bookrags.com/biography/louis-guttman-soc/ | accessdate = 2008-01-01 | year = 2005–2006 | publisher = [[Thomson Gale]] }}</ref> [[Roger Jowell]],<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.city.ac.uk/sociology/dps/SOCIOLOGY_RESEARCH_REPORT_2005-06.pdf | title = Annual Research Report, 2005-2006 | accessdate = 2008-01-01 | format = [[PDF]] | publisher = Department of Sociology, [[City University London]] | pages = 9 }}</ref> [[Elihu Katz]],<ref> {{cite book | author = Dennis, Everette E., and Ellen Wartella (eds) | title = American Communication Research: The Remembered History | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Z9n1HICzx4oC&pg=PA195&dq=%22Helen+Dinerman+Award%22 | accessdate = 2007-12-31 | year = 1996 | publisher = [[Lawrence Erlbaum Associates]] | location = | isbn = 978-0-8058-1744-7 | page = 195 }}</ref> [[Juan Linz]], [[Seymour Martin Lipset]],<ref> {{cite news | title = Hoover Senior Fellow Seymour Martin Lipset Dies | work = [[Business Wire]] | date = 2007-01-03 }}</ref> [[Robert K. Merton]],<ref> {{cite journal | last = Dillman | first = Don A. | title = Helen Dinerman and the Connecting of Science with Practice1 | journal = Newsletter | issue = Second Quarter 2006 | pages = 7–10 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research | url = http://www.crs.wsu.edu/facstaff/dillman/don-dinerman06-brief.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2008-01-01 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070803180728/http://www.crs.wsu.edu/facstaff/dillman/don-dinerman06-brief.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-03}}</ref> [[Elisabeth Noelle-Neumann]],<ref> {{cite book |author1=Salmon, Charles T. |author2=Chi-Yung Moh |lastauthoramp=yes | editor = J. David Kennamer | title = Public Opinion, The Press, and Public Policy | url = https://books.google.com/?id=qTzsujjiQMsC&pg=PA146&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | year = 1994 | publisher = Praeger Publishers | location = [[Westport, Connecticut]] | isbn = 978-0-275-95097-2 | chapter = The Spiral of Silence: Linking Individual and Society Through Communication | page = 146 }}</ref><ref> {{cite book | last = Viswanath | first = K. | editor = Nancy Signorielli | title = Women in Communication: A Biographical Sourcebook | url = https://books.google.com/?id=Jds8Oc1Oqt0C&pg=PA303&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | year = 1996 | publisher = [[Greenwood Press]] | location = [[Westport, Connecticut]] | isbn = 978-0-313-29164-7 | chapter = Elisabeth Noelle-Neumann (1916– ) | page = 303 }}</ref> [[Sidney Verba]],<ref> {{cite journal | title = 2004 Dinerman Award Winner: Dr. Sidney Verba | journal = Newsletter | issue = Second Quarter 2004 | pages = 4–5 | publisher = World Association for Public Opinion Research | url = http://www.unl.edu/WAPOR/Newsletters/2nd%20Q%202004.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2008-01-01 }}</ref> [[Robert Worcester]], and [[Daniel Yankelovich]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.publicagenda.org/aboutpa/aboutpa_whoswho_detail.cfm?list=1 | title = Daniel Yankelovich | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | work = Who's Who at Public Agenda? | publisher = Public Agenda |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070715221908/http://www.publicagenda.org/aboutpa/aboutpa_whoswho_detail.cfm?list=1 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-07-15}}</ref>
== Influence == Richard Morin, former polling director of ''[[The Washington Post]]'', described WAPOR as "the leading professional association of pollsters working outside the United States".<ref> {{cite news | first = Richard | last = Morin | title = Crackdown on Pollsters | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/polls/wat/archive/wat011998.htm | work = [[The Washington Post]] | date = 1998-01-19 | accessdate = 2007-11-03}}</ref> [[Herbert Weisberg]], a [[political scientist]] at [[The Ohio State University]] and former president of the Midwest Political Science Association,<ref> {{cite web | url = https://pro.osu.edu/profiles/weisberg.1/ | title = Dr. Herbert F. Weisberg | accessdate = 2007-11-03 | work = OSU:pro | publisher = [[The Ohio State University]]}}</ref> further credited WAPOR with contributing to the internationalization, and thereby the [[professionalization]], of the field of survey research.<ref> {{cite book | last = Weisberg | first = Herbert F. | title = The Total Survey Error Approach: A Guide to the New Science of Survey Research | url = https://books.google.com/?id=lH2f9Ka60IQC&pg=PA11&dq=%22World+Association+for+Public+Opinion+Research%22 | accessdate = 2007-11-03 | year = 2005 | publisher = [[University of Chicago Press]] | location = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | isbn = 978-0-226-89127-9 | page = 11}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Opinion poll]] * [[Public opinion]]
