(the building is under construction) in 1964 |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1925|5|3}} |birth_place = Kyoto, [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|2008|9|3|1925|5|3}} |death_place = Apt, France |field = Stone sculpture Metagraphie |alma_mater = [[Kobe University]]
[[Tokyo University of the Arts]]
[[École des Beaux-Arts]] |works = ''Walls of Fossiles'' Japan
''Macrocosm and Microcosm'' France
''Key of Love'' Germany
''Echo of laugh'' US etc. | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] (Commandeur)(France·1985) | elected = | website = }} {{nihongo|'''Yasuo Mizui'''|水井　康雄|Mizui Yasuo|extra=30 May 1925 – 3 September 2008}} was a Japanese stone sculptor who lived in France. He prefers abstract form in [[public art|public sculpture]] within architectural contexts and took part in several [[Academic conference|symposia]] on sculpture in Europe, the US, Israel, and Japan.{{cite book|last1=Pas|first1=Johan|title=The Middleheim Collection|date=2010|publisher=S.I. Ludion|location=Antwerp|isbn=978-90-5544-961-3|pages=91–92}} ==Biography== Yasuo Mizui entered into [[Kobe University]] in 1944.{{cite book|last1=Bénézit|first1=Emmanuel|title=Dictionnaire Bénézit|date=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Paris|isbn=2-7000-3040-0|page=685}} During [[World War II]], he worked as technician at a company and learned casting. After his graduation in 1947, he entered [[Tokyo University of the Arts]] and majored in Sculpture. He was taught by Kazuo Kikuchi and [[Hirakushi Denchū]]. The reason of shifting his interest from mechanical engineering to sculpture was because he hoped of possibility of power of art, which has no frontier nor war and he chose "Art [[casting]] – Casting [[Budda|daibutsu]]" as his thesis.{{cite book|last1=Mizui|first1=Yasuo|title=50 ans de Sculpture|date=2003|publisher=Yasuo Mizui|location=Lacoste|page=126}} After graduation from [[Tokyo University of the Arts]] in 1953, he obtained a scholarship from French government to study further at [[École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts]] de Paris from 1953 to 1958, where he learned monumental art and sculpture from [[Alfred Janniot]] and [[Marcel Gimond]]. He apprenticed Apel·les Fenosa from 1954 to 1958 while studying at the university. While visiting the atelier, Fenosa assigned Mizui to create one piece of work made by clay every day upon his arrival. After several months, Mizui felt despair from his own creativity. However, he managed to create one at the last minute. This experience helped his subsequent career to attend the [[International Sculpture Symposium]] and to create large monumental works under the French program 1% for art.{{cite news|url=http://www.lavoixdunord.fr/region/villeneuve-d-ascq-met-a-l-honneur-le-sculpteur-ia28b50417n2754813|title=Villeneuve-d'Ascq met à l'honneur le sculpteur japonais Yasuo Mizui|date=5 April 2015|work=La Voix du Nord|language=French|accessdate=7 February 2016}} ===Works for Olympic games in Japan and France=== He has created walls of sculptures ''Les murs des fossils (Walls of fossils)'' for [[1964 Summer Olympics|Tokyo Olympic games]] in Tokyo, Japan in 1964 and ''Microcosme et macrocosme'' for [[Winter Olympic Games]] in [[Grenoble]], France. [[File:Mizui scans 198.jpeg|230px|right|Les murs des fossiles]][[File:Mizui scans 197.jpeg|230px|right]] ''Les murs des fossils (Walls of Fossils)'' (granite / 2mx 93x 0.3 / 1964 / [[Yoyogi National Gymnasium]]){{cite web|last1=Yoyogi National Gymnasium|title=Art works at Yoyogi National Gymnasium|url=http://www.jpnsport.go.jp/yoyogi/Portals/0/美術作品及び記念作品.pdf|website=Artworks at Yoyogi National Gymnasium|publisher=Japan Sport Council|accessdate=6 February 2016}} Yoyogi National Gymnasium is arena for athletic games, located in Yoyogi Park, Tokyo, designed by [[Kenzo Tange]] and it was built between 1961 and 1964. Mizui received a request from Tange in February 1964 and created the wall of art with ten other assistants in [[List of islands of Japan|Kitagi island]] for three months, then, delivered it to Tokyo in August for completion. Foreign media introduced its works in September. The length of the large abstract wall of reliefs is 93 m in total. They consist of 408 pieces of 1 m 82 cm x 60 cm x 30 cm Mikage stone and the total weight is 160 tons. These Mikage stones come from Kitagi Island, also known as "Stone Island", in [[Okayama]], Japan. His concept ''Walls of Fossiles'' expresses 10 landscapes in his deep involvement with experience of life and nature-like memory as fossils; Travel – Flame – Weight – Perfume – Obsession – Water – Wisdom – Sound – Time – Light. As always, he carved all works by hand using chisels and large and small hammer.{{cite journal|title=Relief concept for Olympic Gymnagium|journal=Geisei Journal|date=30 March 1964|issue=Church of Perfect Liberty}} [[File:04097水井康雄マクロミクロ.JPG|280px|right|Macrocosme et Microcosme]] "Macrocosm and microcosm" (stone / 13 m x 81 x 0.4 / Olympic Village Grenoble).{{cite web|title=Microcosme et Macrocosme|url=http://www.museedelaville.agglo-sqy.fr/fileadmin/musee/MEDIA/VAH/Laissez-vs_conter/Laissez_vous_conter_l%20art_public.pdf|website=Musée de la ville de Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines|publisher=Hôtel d'agglomération de Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines|accessdate=14 February 2016|location=Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines|page=2|language=French|format=PDF}} Two walls of 40 m – the "macrocosm and microcosm" – are expressed as the maximum and the minimum of the world. "The Maximum" symbolizes the great life of nature as Sun, Forest, Mountain, Sea, and River beyond the individual matter and "the Minimum" symbolizes the inner conflict of human beings. They are expressed the world of nature and human beings.{{cite news|title=Repainting old city|work=Asahi Shimbun|publisher=The Asahi Shimbun Company|date=8 October 1967}} [[File:04094水井康雄.JPG|150px|left|マルロー]]Tadao Takemoto, who translated the book "Anti-retrospective" (Shincho Sha, Japan, 1977) by [[André Malraux]], often referred to Mizui about him. During the term, he, Minister of Cultural Affairs under Charles de Gaulle regime, who has deep knowledge of arts, visited the Olympic Village. He saw the wall of art and said to Mizui "Excellent!".{{cite journal|title=1% for art in France – Giving urban city for soul and artists for creative activities|journal=Asahi Journal|date=1 February 1977|issue=The Asahi Shimbun company}} ===1% for art=== [[File:04153開く壁.JPG|280px|right|Wall that Opens]] In France, the law of 1951 provides that 1% of the state budget is spent on the decoration of public buildings with artwork. The majority of the works of Mizui in France are created under [[percent for art|1% for art]]. He has been built 26 sculptures between 1968 and 1982(for 14 years).{{cite news|last1=Shuzo|first1=Yasui|title=With large sculpture, ask Yasuo Mizui|issue=Evening post|publisher=The Mainichi Newspapers Co., Ltd|date=17 January 1974|location=Tokyo, Japan|language=Japanese}} For The first order from French cultural ministry was to create sculpture at Bordeaux University (department of law) in 1968, where he built ''Jet d'eau pétrifiée (Petrified waterjet)''.{{cite web|title=Œuvres du "1% artistique"|url=http://patrimoine.bordeaux.free.fr/bordeauxIV.html|website=Art&Fac 2010|publisher=Association C'Dynamique|accessdate=14 February 2016|language=French}} This request was made after his reputation towards Microcosme et Macrocosme at Winter Olympic games in Grenoble. ''Le Mur qui s'ouvre (Wall that Opens)''(cement / 4.5m x 13 x 1.4 / 1972/ located in Lycée Louis Bascan, [[Rambouillet]]) is a retaining wall. The artist used molds of expanded polyester material that cut through the electrical resistance, a very specific technique that Mizui has obtained from his engineering background.{{cite journal|title=Memorandum of 1% for art in France|journal=Sankei Shimbun|date=18 November 1983|issue=Evening post|publisher=Sankei Shimbun Co., Ltd|location=Tokyo, Japan|language=Japanese}} ===Symposium=== [[File:Clef d'Amour Berlin 2013.jpg|230px|right|Clet d'amour]] The sculpture symposium gave Mizui an opportunity for a new direction to develop and promote a sense of sculptural monumentality in the urban beauty. It also provided competitions among artists to demonstrate one's ability to create the same material. This movement has been achieved since 1959 in [[:de:Symposion europäischer Bildhauer 1961–1963|St. Margrethen]] in Germany. The first participation of Mizui was in Austria in 1960. He discovered the charm of work from large stone blocks of 4 meters. In 1962, he created the work, ''Clef d'amour (Key of Love)'' (stone /4m x 0.9 x 0.6) before the [[Berlin Wall]] in Germany. The new bank had the slogan of this symposium: "The wall to the east, creating a sculpture to the west ." The Symposium was awarded German critique prize. He stated " There is a wall between east and west. The wall he created a sad story every day. Our silent anger supported this meeting." Location of the statue has been moved and currently presented at Berlin Square in Germany.Yasuo Mizui «La fête de la Carrière», articles over "Geijyutsushinncho", édition [[Shinchōsha]] Japan, {{p.|80-82}} The following year in 1963, he participated International Sculpture Symposium at [[Manazuru]] City, [[Kanagawa|Kanagawa Prefecture]] in Japan, as a leader, under the financial support from [[Asahi Shimbun Company]], where 11 other sculptors from eight different countries also participated.{{cite news|last1=Yasuo|first1=Kamon|title=Expectation for Sculpture Symposium|issue=Morning Post|publisher=Asahi Shimbun Company|date=24 June 1963|location=Tokyo, Japan|language=Japanese}} ===Diagonal Yin Yang=== [[File:00396石の彫刻陰陽.JPG|200px|right|Yin Yang]][[File:04123斜陰陽.JPG|200px|right|Yin Yang]][[File:04115斜陰陽.JPG|200px|right|Yin Yang]] There is a [[Fontaine-de-Vaucluse]] near to Lacoste where Mizui lived. This is a mysterious fountain, which has love story, dated back to the 14th century. He stated: "Why not, [[Nachi Falls]] gush somewhere in France as the rain hollows constantly rocks the fountain." When he visited Nachi Falls in Japan later on, his heart and body trembled in front of the cascade and he was convinced: " Waterfall Nachi had really pierced the earth and it rebounds into Fontaine-de-Valucluse." He, at the age of 70 years old, realized "Diagonal Yin Yang" was divided between Japan and France; Two paths, two unfinished cultures. He often questions the place of the two extremes in his sculptural work where he felt caught between the [[Hammer (tool)]] and [[Anvil (tool)|Anvil]]. Along with these two realizations that coexist in his work, one under the influence of another, the Yin and Yang characters are also identified by Mizui, Japan as ( ''Yin'' ), and France as ( ''Yang'' ). This assimilation takes more consistency with the movement that brings these two countries. It is in the conversation and the confrontation between the aspects [[Yin and Yang]], which constantly oppose each other, are answered, push, and embraces he discovers, though this sculpture as a new form. River, a house, or a woman appearance, are as Yin elements. While a flower, a tree, an animal, and a patron will generally have the character of Yang. He constantly questions the expression of his sculpture in terms of strengths ''Yin'' or ''Yang''. He himself says "The response looks like a mask play between truth and falsehood."{{cite book|last1=Mizui|first1=Yasuo|title=Catalogue Diagonal Yin Yang|date=1995|publisher=Yasuo Mizui|location=Tokyo, Japan|language=Japanese, French}} Mizui heard by his friend, Tadao Takemoto, who is the writer of ''Andre Malraux and Nachi Waterfall''; [[André Malraux]] said "Nachi Waterfall is the backbone of the [[Shintoism]]."{{cite book|last1=Takemoto|first1=Tadao|title=André Malraux et la cascade de Nachi|date=1989|publisher=Julliard|location=Paris, France|isbn=2260006558|language=French}} ''Diagonal Yin Yang'' is a series of 40 stone sculptures, made in Japan for the exhibition at Gallery Tatuno Hiranomachi, [[Osaka]], Japan, in 1965. After this exhibition, all his works were transferred to France, in the garden of his residence in Lacoste. Two statues were offered on the occasion of the exhibition at [[Luxeuil-les-Bains]] in 2013.{{cite web|title=Exposition Rétrospective Mizui|url=http://www.musees-franchecomte.com/gallery_files/site_1/829/dp-exposition-mizui-luxeuil-les-bains-2013.pdf|website=musees-franchecomte.com|publisher=Tourist office of Luxeuil-les-bains|accessdate=15 February 2016|language=French|date=2003}} ===Wall of Hope=== [[File:000717希望の壁.JPG|333px|right|Le Mur de l'Espoir]] In 1985, during a project with Seita Onishi, a Japanese business man, and philanthropist, Mizui was keen on the actor [[James Dean]]. Together, they had a goal, to create a James Dean Center, which would be located in [[Cholame]], in California in the United States, near the place of the fatal car accident of James Dean. [[File:Le mur de l'espoir.JPG|150px|left|Wall of Hope]]Earlier year in 1981, Mizui had been created and placed chromium cenotaph for James Dean, commissioned by Onishi, near to the place his accident.{{cite web|title=Obsessed by James Dean, Japan's Seita Onishi Makes a Monument to That Fallen Rebel His Cause|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20120914,00.html|website=People|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=17 February 2016|pages=6|date=7 August 1989}} Mizui worked on James Dean Center project for three years, creating sketches and sculptures, as well as visiting the United States. Following a conflict of opinion with the owner of the proposed Center site, the project could not be fulfilled. Yet the "Wall of Hope" remains, a monumental sculpture (Limestone/13 x 4,50 x 1,20 m) dedicated to the memory of James Dean; this sculpture took three years for him to complete; it consists of 150 tons of stone extracted from the quarry of [[Lacoste]], in the village where he lived. On one of the sides of the "Wall of Hope", he sculpted in stone the face of the film icon. "I said to myself, the three masterpieces of James Dean saved his fans from despair, the desperate walls open and give us the light of hope", the artist explains.{{cite book|last1=Coghe|first1=Jean-Noël|title=Jimmy the Kid : James Dean secret : on a tous quelque chose de James Dean--|date=2007|publisher=Hugo doc|location=[Paris]|isbn=978-2755601763|page=364|language=French}} The "Wall of Hope" was inaugurated in 2006, 51 years after the death of the actor, and, though not in California, it welcomes visitors to the garden, like an open-air museum, of Mizui, in Lacoste.{{cite book|last1=Yasuo|first1=Mizui|title=50ans de Sculpture|date=2003|publisher=Yasuo Mizui|location=Tokyo, Japan|page=82|language=French, Japanese}} ===Stone and Asceticism=== Mizui said: "Given the immense nature, I felt myself very small. In addition, the stone has rough context, but it is already so beautiful. Although I talked, insulted, and sighed him, he remained transferable and quietly annoyed in spite of my pleas and anger. However, after some time, the stone started to talk. It was he who guided me;'' Not so! And there! Yes, like this.'' ''If I can one day to melt into the divine nothingness, my sculpture will remain as an offering to the great nature."{{cite journal|title=Pierre et Ascese|journal=Mizue|date=October 1963|publisher=Bijyutsu Shuppan Sha Co., Ltd|location=Tokyo, Japan|language=Japanese}} Jean- Rosenberg, science professor at [[University of Poitiers]], told about the sculpture of Mizui; ''In his non-figurative art, the temporal dimension is absent. There are no messages coded by symbols or figures. His work is cosmic. One feels the origin of life and evolution; it represents the universal entities, which have not individualized, but as they stand at the beginning of evolution.''Yasuo Mizui, ''50ans de Sculpture'', {{p.|125}},2003 === Métagraphie === [[File:Métagraphie Mizui,jpg modifié-1.jpg|200px|right|métagraphie]] The technique of compressing a color between two sheets of paper or two other materials gave rise to unexpected fantastic images. The artist analyzed the causality of phenomena that may be considered accidental. In other words, it is to introduce the power of the will in the creation of such phenomena, by developing a technique and practice. This process expresses the reflection, change, succession, and the fact of going beyond, beside, and between etc. Obtained by a non-reproducible process, the métagraphie implies that the artist makes the slide watercolor on waterproof paper, then lets it have the chance to act on the matter. His own response is to find the right balance between the fluidity of watercolor and the exposure time. There are similar techniques, such as pressed oil, starch-pressed, and the decal. But the manner and the choice of material of Mizui are different.{{cite web|title=Exposition Retrospective Mizui|url=http://www.musees-franchecomte.com/gallery_files/site_1/829/dp-exposition-mizui-luxeuil-les-bains-2013.pdf|website=Musees-franchecomte|publisher=Association L'art dans la Rue|accessdate=17 February 2016|language=French|date=September 2013}} An international critic of Fine Arts, Sakae Hasegawa, said in 1984: "When I saw this painting for the first time, I thought this was a picture of a snowy mountain. But looking closer, it was not a picture and this picture had a strong resonance in me, it perceives cold silence. I find this painting conveys a philosophical and meditative opening, as if he could let the silence of the heart.".Yasuo Mizui, ''50ans de Sculpture'', 2003 ===Four completed forms=== ;1. The sculpture of the oscillation / ''Oscillo-Relief'', 1972–1982 ''Oscillo-Relief'' cut is the shape obtained by the vertical oscillatory motion and horizontal oscillation of an electrical resistance. This free form is not the result of a prior plan, but the technique requires precise control. ''Oscillo-Relief'' is a fundamental invention of Mizui. He applied the technique to his sculptures in 1972. He was invited for The 2nd Henry Moore Grand Prize Exhibition at [[Hakone Open-Air Museum]], in [[Nagano Prefecture]], Japan in 1981, created ''Oscillo-complex''(stone / 3m x 1.3 x 1.2), and received Special Prize at the exhibition.{{cite news|title=The 2nd Henry Moore Grand Prize Exhibition The Hakone Open-Air Museum|publisher=The Hakone Open-Air Museum|date=1981|location=Hakone|language=English, Japanese|format=Exhibition catalogue}} [[File:04150コスモス.JPG|160px|right|cosmos]] ;2. The Wall Sculpture, 1964 – "Cosmos"(stone / 15m x 18 x 0.06 / 1970 / Lycée Louis Armand in [[Villefranche-sur-Saône]] ).{{cite web|title=Culture ; Délégation aux arts plastiques ; Sous-direction de la décentralisation et du soutien à la création ; Bureau commande publique, 1%|url=https://www.siv.archives-nationales.culture.gouv.fr/siv/rechercheconsultation/consultation/ir/consultationIR.action?udId=d_72&irId=FRAN_IR_015069|website=Archives Nationales (France)|publisher=Archives Nationales (France)|accessdate=18 February 2016|location=Pierrefitte-sur-Seine|language=French}} 360 flagstones of [[Comblanchien]], unit of 6 cm thick, are firmly fixed on the wall. Mizui himself said, "I wanted to create a shadow graphics and light evoking heaven, earth and man.".Yasuo Mizui, ''50ans de Sculpture'', 2003,{{p.|29}} The wall sculpture recalls, in formal terms, ''Walls of Fossiles'' and "Macrocosme et Microcosme". [[File:04135ネケブ.JPG|130px|right|degree=90| Néguev]] ;3. The sculpture "Largeg Head", 1960–1971 "Hommage à Néguev (To Neguev)" (marble / 3.7m x 1.7 x 0.6 / 1962 / [[Mitzpe Ramon]], Israel, Symposium) performed on the occasion of a Symposium in Israel. About this experience, the artist expresses himself in these words: ''It was a real brainwashing life for two months in the Negev desert. I felt my sculpture as a drop in the sea with immensity of nature. This is the first time that I could hold chisel with sincerely humble. When I made an elliptical hole in the top part, I felt that sun light was rising towards me.''{{cite news|last1=Matsumura|first1=Kazuo|title=Great Nature Paean|issue=Evening Post|publisher=Sankei Shimbun Co., Ltd|date=2 December 1985|language=Japanese}} [[File:04129ジブザグ.JPG|130px|right|degree=90|ZigZag]] ;4. The Sculpture ZIG and ZAG, 1973–1974 "ZIG and ZAG" (stone / 2m x 0.4 x 0.4 / 1973 / [[Savannah College of Art and Design]], [[Lacoste, Vaucluse|Lacoste]]). Mizui first worked with blocks of polystyrene by cutting them to see the final shape of sculpture. He directed dozens of works like this. In the fifties, Parisian artists like to establish their workshop in [[Provence]]. The New Yorker painter, Bernard Pfriem, opened an art school to bring American students in the center of the village of Lacoste, France.{{cite web|title=An Unofficial History of the Lacoste School of the Arts|url=https://lacostoise.wordpress.com/|website=Souvenirs de Lacoste|publisher=Worldpress.com|accessdate=18 February 2016}} This school is located in a large house located next to the ancient castle, The Marquis de Sade. He had remained relationship with the school for 20 years, taught students about stone sculpture every summer, and made one piece of work with them every year.{{cite book|last1=Mizui|first1=Yasuo|title=50ans de Sculpture|date=2003|location=Tokyo|page=34|language=French, Japanese}} == Selected chronology == * 1925 Born on 30 May in Kyoto, Japan * 1944 Graduated from Kyoto Daiichi Industrial high school in Kyoto, Japan, majored in mechanical engineering * 1945 During World War II, worked as a technician in Hyogo, Japan * 1947 Graduated from Kobe University in Hyogo, Japan, majored in mechanical engineering * 1953 Graduated from Tokyo University of the Arts in Tokyo, Japan, majored in sculpture * 1953 Obtained scholarship from French government to study at École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, France, majored in Sculpture * 1954 (until 1958) Apprenticed from Apel·les Fenosa in Paris, France * 1958 Graduated from École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, France * 1959 Participated [[Biennale de Paris]] France, awarded A. {{Infobox artist | name = Yun Bing | native_name = 惲冰 | native_name_lang = zh | birth_place = [[Wujin District]], [[Changzhou]] | known_for = | notable_works = ''Hairpin Scroll'' (簪花图轴) (1735–1796),
''Quiet Provisions of the Studio'' (书房清供图) (1735–1796) | style = [[Bird-and-flower painting]], "Boneless" technique | movement = | spouse = Mao Hongtiao (毛鸿调) | module = {{Infobox Chinese|child=yes |t=惲冰 |s=恽冰 |p=Yùn Bīng |w=Yün Ping |altname = Qingyu |c2 = {{linktext|清|於}} |p2 = Qīngyū |w2 = Ch'ing-yü }} | patrons = | memorials = }} '''Yun Bing''' ({{zh|c=惲冰}}, dates unknown), courtesy names Qingyu ({{zh|c=清於}}) and Haoru ({{zh|c=浩如}}), was a Chinese painter during the [[Qianlong]] era. She is well known for her [[bird-and-flower painting]]s executing the "boneless" technique, and became the most famed of the Yun family's female artists.{{cite|title=毗陵望族恽氏家族文化成就考述|trans-title=Discussion of the achievements of the influential family near the mound, the Yun clan|language=Chinese|author=Lu Haiyang 路海洋|journal=Changzhou gong xueyuan xuebao (shekeban)|volume=31|issue=1|date=2013|pages=1-7}} ==Biography== Yun was born to an artistic family in Wujin District of [[Changzhou]], the granddaughter of the famed painter [[Yun Shouping]]. Her niece [[Yun Zhu]] was also a talented artists. Though her birth and death dates are unknown, one of her paintings in the [[Shanghai Museum]] is dated to 1750.{{cite|title=闺阁丹青没骨情——常州画派女画家及其绘画艺术述论|trans-title=Boneless emotion in paintings from the lady's chambers: an overview of female artists in Changzhou's art scene and their artistic techniques|language=Chinese|author=Wen Xianglei 文祥磊|journal=Yishupin 艺术品|issue=3|date=2017|pages=40-53}} She married Mao Hongtiao, also from Wujin, and the two sold paintings and wrote poetry to support their family. One of Yun's granddaughters, named Zhou ({{zh|c=周}}), was recorded in the Yun family [[genealogy book]], which has been used to suggest that her artistic skills were worthy of the Yun clan. ==Art== Yun's painting style was heavily influenced by her family's preference for the "boneless" technique. She predominantly painted [[bird-and-flower painting]]s, but also painted people, one of which depicts a woman doing her hair known as the ''Hairpin Scroll'' (簪花图轴). Yun is often compared with her contemporary [[Ma Quan]], who similarly specialised in [[bird-and-flower painting]] but favoured strong outlines. The ''Chuyue jiexu wenjian lu'' (初月接续闻见录), compiled in 1818, describes how people throughout the [[Jiangnan]] region described them as the "two without parallel" ({{zh|c=两绝}}){{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.cn/o/2017-11-28/doc-ifypacti8770528.shtml|title=浙博明清女性画家展：看古代闺阁付诸笔端的闲情与才思|trans-title=Zhejiang museum's exhibition of Ming and Qing female artists: the leisure and creativity from the end of a brush in ancient ladies' chambers|editor=Gui Qiang 桂强|publisher=Sina|date=28 November 2017|access-date=28 July 2018}} During his tenure as [[Viceroy of Liangjiang|governor-general of Liangjiang]], Yi Jishan presented some of Yun's works to [[Empress Xiaoshengxian|Empress Dowager Chongqing]] who in turn showed them to the [[Qianlong Emperor]]. The emperor was reportedly so impressed that he wrote a poem praising her art, after which Yun's reputation as a painter spread. ==Gallery== File:MET DP153920.jpg|''Flower Study'' (花卉圖), [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] File:MET DP153921.jpg|''Flower Study'' (花卉圖）, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book | title=Views from Jade Terrace: Chinese women artists, 1300-1912 | author-last=Smith Weidner |author-first=Martha | place=Indianapolis |publisher=Indianapolis Museum of Art | date=1988 | isbn=9780847810031 }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yun, Bing}} [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:Qing dynasty painters]] [[Category:Women's history]] [[Category:Chinese women artists]] [[Category:18th-century Chinese painters]] [[Category:18th-century Chinese women]] [[Category:Painters from Jiangsu]]
